AI.conclusion: FCD provides a powerful framework for continuous parametric decomposition of time-series data with physical interpretability, applicable across physics, medicine, finance, and machine learning for signal analysis, feature extraction, and enhanced model performance.

title: Generalizing from References using a Multi-Task Reference and Goal-Driven RL Framework
summary: Learning agile humanoid behaviors from human motion offers a powerful route to natural, coordinated control, but existing approaches face a persistent trade-off: reference-tracking policies are often brittle outside the demonstration dataset, while purely task-driven Reinforcement Learning (RL) can achieve adaptability at the cost of motion quality. We introduce a unified multi-task RL framework that bridges this gap by treating reference motion as a prior for behavioral shaping rather than a deployment-time constraint. A single goal-conditioned policy is trained jointly on two tasks that share the same observation and action spaces, but differ in their initialization schemes, command spaces, and reward structures: (i) a reference-guided imitation task in which reference trajectories define dense imitation rewards but are not provided as policy inputs, and (ii) a goal-conditioned generalization task in which goals are sampled independently of any reference and where rewards reflect only task success. By co-optimizing these objectives within a shared formulation, the policy acquires structured, human-like motor skills from dense reference supervision while learning to adapt these skills to novel goals and initial conditions. This is achieved without adversarial objectives, explicit trajectory tracking, phase variables, or reference-dependent inference. We evaluate the method on a challenging box-based parkour playground that demands diverse athletic behaviors (e.g., jumping and climbing), and show that the learned controller transfers beyond the reference distribution while preserving motion naturalness. Finally, we demonstrate long-horizon behavior generation by composing multiple learned skills, illustrating the flexibility of the learned polices in complex scenarios.

AI.tldr: Multi-task RL framework bridges imitation learning and task-driven RL by treating reference motion as behavioral prior, enabling natural human-like skills that adapt to novel goals without explicit tracking.
AI.motivation: Existing approaches face trade-off: reference-tracking policies are brittle outside demonstration data, while purely task-driven RL sacrifices motion quality for adaptability. Need unified approach that preserves natural motion while enabling generalization.
AI.method: Multi-task RL framework with single goal-conditioned policy trained jointly on two tasks: (1) reference-guided imitation task with dense imitation rewards (reference not as policy input), and (2) goal-conditioned generalization task with only task success rewards. No adversarial objectives, explicit tracking, phase variables, or reference-dependent inference.
AI.result: Learned controller transfers beyond reference distribution while preserving motion naturalness. Evaluated on challenging box-based parkour playground requiring diverse athletic behaviors (jumping, climbing). Demonstrates long-horizon behavior generation by composing multiple learned skills.
AI.conclusion: Unified framework successfully bridges imitation learning and task-driven RL, enabling policies to acquire structured human-like motor skills from reference supervision while learning to adapt these skills to novel goals and conditions without compromising motion quality.

title: CLIPoint3D: Language-Grounded Few-Shot Unsupervised 3D Point Cloud Domain Adaptation
summary: Recent vision-language models (VLMs) such as CLIP demonstrate impressive cross-modal reasoning, extending beyond images to 3D perception. Yet, these models remain fragile under domain shifts, especially when adapting from synthetic to real-world point clouds. Conventional 3D domain adaptation approaches rely on heavy trainable encoders, yielding strong accuracy but at the cost of efficiency. We introduce CLIPoint3D, the first framework for few-shot unsupervised 3D point cloud domain adaptation built upon CLIP. Our approach projects 3D samples into multiple depth maps and exploits the frozen CLIP backbone, refined through a knowledge-driven prompt tuning scheme that integrates high-level language priors with geometric cues from a lightweight 3D encoder. To adapt task-specific features effectively, we apply parameter-efficient fine-tuning to CLIP's encoders and design an entropy-guided view sampling strategy for selecting confident projections. Furthermore, an optimal transport-based alignment loss and an uncertainty-aware prototype alignment loss collaboratively bridge source-target distribution gaps while maintaining class separability. Extensive experiments on PointDA-10 and GraspNetPC-10 benchmarks show that CLIPoint3D achieves consistent 3-16% accuracy gains over both CLIP-based and conventional encoder-based baselines. Codes are available at https://github.com/SarthakM320/CLIPoint3D.

AI.tldr: CLIPoint3D is a few-shot unsupervised 3D point cloud domain adaptation framework that leverages frozen CLIP backbones with knowledge-driven prompt tuning and geometric cues to bridge synthetic-to-real domain gaps efficiently.
AI.motivation: Current VLMs like CLIP show cross-modal reasoning but are fragile under domain shifts, especially from synthetic to real-world point clouds. Conventional 3D domain adaptation methods use heavy trainable encoders that sacrifice efficiency for accuracy.
AI.method: Projects 3D samples into multiple depth maps, uses frozen CLIP backbone refined through knowledge-driven prompt tuning that integrates language priors with geometric cues from lightweight 3D encoder. Includes parameter-efficient fine-tuning, entropy-guided view sampling, optimal transport-based alignment loss, and uncertainty-aware prototype alignment loss.
AI.result: Achieves consistent 3-16% accuracy gains over both CLIP-based and conventional encoder-based baselines on PointDA-10 and GraspNetPC-10 benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: CLIPoint3D provides an efficient framework for few-shot unsupervised 3D domain adaptation that effectively bridges source-target distribution gaps while maintaining class separability, outperforming existing methods.

title: From Logs to Language: Learning Optimal Verbalization for LLM-Based Recommendation in Production
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are promising backbones for generative recommender systems, yet a key challenge remains underexplored: verbalization, i.e., converting structured user interaction logs into effective natural language inputs. Existing methods rely on rigid templates that simply concatenate fields, yielding suboptimal representations for recommendation. We propose a data-centric framework that learns verbalization for LLM-based recommendation. Using reinforcement learning, a verbalization agent transforms raw interaction histories into optimized textual contexts, with recommendation accuracy as the training signal. This agent learns to filter noise, incorporate relevant metadata, and reorganize information to improve downstream predictions. Experiments on a large-scale industrial streaming dataset show that learned verbalization delivers up to 93% relative improvement in discovery item recommendation accuracy over template-based baselines. Further analysis reveals emergent strategies such as user interest summarization, noise removal, and syntax normalization, offering insights into effective context construction for LLM-based recommender systems.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a reinforcement learning framework to learn optimal verbalization strategies for converting structured user interaction data into natural language inputs for LLM-based recommender systems, achieving significant accuracy improvements over template-based methods.
AI.motivation: Current LLM-based recommender systems use rigid templates to convert structured user interaction logs into natural language, which yields suboptimal representations. There's a need for better verbalization methods that can effectively transform structured data into textual contexts that LLMs can understand for improved recommendation accuracy.
AI.method: A data-centric framework using reinforcement learning, where a verbalization agent learns to transform raw interaction histories into optimized textual contexts. The agent uses recommendation accuracy as the training signal and learns strategies like filtering noise, incorporating relevant metadata, and reorganizing information.
AI.result: Experiments on a large-scale industrial streaming dataset show up to 93% relative improvement in discovery item recommendation accuracy over template-based baselines. The learned verbalization reveals emergent strategies including user interest summarization, noise removal, and syntax normalization.
AI.conclusion: Learned verbalization through reinforcement learning significantly outperforms template-based methods for LLM-based recommender systems, providing insights into effective context construction strategies that can be adapted to various recommendation scenarios.

title: FGFRFT: Fast Graph Fractional FourierTransform via Fourier Series Approximation
summary: The graph fractional Fourier transform (GFRFT) generalizes the graph Fourier transform (GFT) but suffers from a significant computational bottleneck: determining the optimal transform order requires expensive eigendecomposition and matrix multiplication, leading to $O(N^3)$ complexity. To address this issue, we propose a fast GFRFT (FGFRFT) algorithm for unitary GFT matrices based on Fourier series approximation and an efficient caching strategy. FGFRFT reduces the complexity of generating transform matrices to $O(2LN^2)$ while preserving differentiability, thereby enabling adaptive order learning. We validate the algorithm through theoretical analysis, approximation accuracy tests, and order learning experiments. Furthermore, we demonstrate its practical efficacy for image and point cloud denoising and present the fractional specformer, which integrates the FGFRFT into the specformer architecture. This integration enables the model to overcome the limitations of a fixed GFT basis and learn optimal fractional orders for complex data. Experimental results confirm that the proposed algorithm significantly accelerates computation and achieves superior performance compared with the GFRFT.

AI.tldr: Proposed FGFRFT algorithm reduces GFRFT complexity from O(N³) to O(2LN²) using Fourier series approximation and caching, enabling adaptive order learning and integration into specformer architecture for improved performance.
AI.motivation: The graph fractional Fourier transform (GFRFT) generalizes GFT but has O(N³) computational complexity due to eigendecomposition and matrix multiplication, making it impractical for large-scale applications and preventing adaptive order learning.
AI.method: Developed fast GFRFT (FGFRFT) algorithm based on Fourier series approximation and efficient caching strategy for unitary GFT matrices, reducing complexity while preserving differentiability for gradient-based optimization.
AI.result: FGFRFT reduces transform matrix generation complexity to O(2LN²), achieves high approximation accuracy, enables adaptive order learning, and when integrated into fractional specformer, outperforms GFRFT in image and point cloud denoising tasks.
AI.conclusion: The FGFRFT algorithm successfully addresses GFRFT's computational bottleneck, enabling efficient fractional order learning and integration into neural architectures for improved performance on complex graph data processing tasks.

title: Grasp to Act: Dexterous Grasping for Tool Use in Dynamic Settings
comment: Result videos can be found at https://grasp2act.github.io/
summary: Achieving robust grasping with dexterous hands remains challenging, especially when manipulation involves dynamic forces such as impacts, torques, and continuous resistance--situations common in real-world tool use. Existing methods largely optimize grasps for static geometric stability and often fail once external forces arise during manipulation. We present Grasp-to-Act, a hybrid system that combines physics-based grasp optimization with reinforcement-learning-based grasp adaptation to maintain stable grasps throughout functional manipulation tasks. Our method synthesizes robust grasp configurations informed by human demonstrations and employs an adaptive controller that residually issues joint corrections to prevent in-hand slip while tracking the object trajectory. Grasp-to-Act enables robust zero-shot sim-to-real transfer across five dynamic tool-use tasks--hammering, sawing, cutting, stirring, and scooping--consistently outperforming baselines. Across simulation and real-world hardware trials with a 16-DoF dexterous hand, our method reduces translational and rotational in-hand slip and achieves the highest task completion rates, demonstrating stable functional grasps under dynamic, contact-rich conditions.

AI.tldr: Grasp-to-Act combines physics-based grasp optimization with RL-based adaptation to maintain stable grasps during dynamic tool-use tasks, enabling robust sim-to-real transfer across hammering, sawing, cutting, stirring, and scooping.
AI.motivation: Existing grasp optimization methods focus on static geometric stability but fail when external dynamic forces (impacts, torques, continuous resistance) arise during real-world tool manipulation tasks.
AI.method: Hybrid system combining physics-based grasp optimization with reinforcement-learning-based grasp adaptation. Synthesizes robust grasp configurations from human demonstrations and uses adaptive controller that issues residual joint corrections to prevent slip while tracking object trajectory.
AI.result: Enables robust zero-shot sim-to-real transfer across five dynamic tool-use tasks (hammering, sawing, cutting, stirring, scooping). Reduces translational and rotational in-hand slip, achieves highest task completion rates in simulation and real-world trials with 16-DoF dexterous hand.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates stable functional grasps under dynamic, contact-rich conditions, consistently outperforming baselines and showing practical applicability for real-world dexterous manipulation tasks.

title: SimLBR: Learning to Detect Fake Images by Learning to Detect Real Images
summary: The rapid advancement of generative models has made the detection of AI-generated images a critical challenge for both research and society. Recent works have shown that most state-of-the-art fake image detection methods overfit to their training data and catastrophically fail when evaluated on curated hard test sets with strong distribution shifts. In this work, we argue that it is more principled to learn a tight decision boundary around the real image distribution and treat the fake category as a sink class. To this end, we propose SimLBR, a simple and efficient framework for fake image detection using Latent Blending Regularization (LBR). Our method significantly improves cross-generator generalization, achieving up to +24.85\% accuracy and +69.62\% recall on the challenging Chameleon benchmark. SimLBR is also highly efficient, training orders of magnitude faster than existing approaches. Furthermore, we emphasize the need for reliability-oriented evaluation in fake image detection, introducing risk-adjusted metrics and worst-case estimates to better assess model robustness. All code and models will be released on HuggingFace and GitHub.

AI.tldr: SimLBR proposes a simple fake image detection framework using Latent Blending Regularization that learns a tight decision boundary around real images, treating fakes as a sink class, achieving strong cross-generator generalization with high efficiency.
AI.motivation: Current fake image detection methods overfit to training data and fail catastrophically on hard test sets with distribution shifts. There's a need for more robust and reliable detection approaches that generalize across different generators.
AI.method: SimLBR uses Latent Blending Regularization to learn a tight decision boundary around the real image distribution, treating fake images as a sink class. The approach focuses on modeling the real image manifold rather than trying to capture all possible fake variations.
AI.result: Achieves up to +24.85% accuracy and +69.62% recall on the challenging Chameleon benchmark, with orders of magnitude faster training than existing approaches. Also introduces reliability-oriented evaluation metrics.
AI.conclusion: Learning a tight decision boundary around real images is a more principled approach for fake image detection, enabling better cross-generator generalization and efficiency. The paper also emphasizes the importance of reliability-oriented evaluation for assessing model robustness.

title: CausalReasoningBenchmark: A Real-World Benchmark for Disentangled Evaluation of Causal Identification and Estimation
summary: Many benchmarks for automated causal inference evaluate a system's performance based on a single numerical output, such as an Average Treatment Effect (ATE). This approach conflates two distinct steps in causal analysis: identification-formulating a valid research design under stated assumptions-and estimation-implementing that design numerically on finite data. We introduce CausalReasoningBenchmark, a benchmark of 173 queries across 138 real-world datasets, curated from 85 peer-reviewed research papers and four widely-used causal-inference textbooks. For each query a system must produce (i) a structured identification specification that names the strategy, the treatment, outcome, and control variables, and all design-specific elements, and (ii) a point estimate with a standard error. By scoring these two components separately, our benchmark enables granular diagnosis: it distinguishes failures in causal reasoning from errors in numerical execution. Baseline results with a state-of-the-art LLM show that, while the model correctly identifies the high-level strategy in 84 % of cases, full identification-specification correctness drops to only 30 %, revealing that the bottleneck lies in the nuanced details of research design rather than in computation. CausalReasoningBenchmark is publicly available on Hugging Face and is designed to foster the development of more robust automated causal-inference systems.

AI.tldr: CausalReasoningBenchmark evaluates automated causal inference systems by separating identification (research design) from estimation (numerical computation), using 173 queries from 138 real-world datasets to diagnose where systems fail.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks conflate identification and estimation in causal inference, evaluating systems based only on single numerical outputs like ATE. This makes it impossible to distinguish failures in causal reasoning from errors in numerical computation.
AI.method: Created a benchmark of 173 queries across 138 real-world datasets curated from 85 peer-reviewed papers and 4 causal inference textbooks. Each query requires: (1) structured identification specification (strategy, treatment, outcome, control variables, design elements), and (2) point estimate with standard error. Scores these components separately.
AI.result: Baseline results with a state-of-the-art LLM show 84% correct high-level strategy identification, but only 30% full identification-specification correctness. This reveals the bottleneck is in nuanced research design details, not computation.
AI.conclusion: CausalReasoningBenchmark enables granular diagnosis of automated causal inference systems by separating identification from estimation, revealing that current systems struggle with detailed research design specification despite understanding high-level strategies.

title: Symbol-Aware Precoder Design for Physical-Layer Anonymous Communications
comment: This paper has been submitted for possible journal publication
summary: Physical-layer characteristics, such as channel state information (CSI) and transmitter noise induced by hardware impairments, are often uniquely associated with a transmitter. This paper investigates transmitter anonymity at the physical layer from a signal design perspective. We consider an anonymous communication problem where the receiver should reliably decode the signal from the transmitter but should not make use of the signal to infer the transmitter's identity.Transmitter anonymity is quantified using a Kullback-Leibler divergence (KLD)-based metric, which enables the formulation of explicit anonymity constraints in the precoder design.We then propose an anonymous symbol-level precoding strategy that preserves reliable communication under spatial multiplexing while preventing transmitter identification. The proposed framework employs a partitioned equal-gain combining (P-EGC) scheme that leverages receiver diversity without requiring transmitter-specific CSI. Simulation results demonstrate anonymity-reliability tradeoffs across different signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs) and numbers of data streams. Moreover, the results reveal opposite trends of anonymity with respect to transmitter-dependent noise variations in the low-SNR and high-SNR regimes.

AI.tldr: Anonymous physical-layer communication using symbol-level precoding to prevent transmitter identification while maintaining reliable data transmission.
AI.motivation: Physical-layer characteristics like CSI and hardware noise can uniquely identify transmitters, creating privacy concerns. The paper aims to enable anonymous communication where receivers can decode signals but cannot identify the transmitter.
AI.method: Proposes anonymous symbol-level precoding with KLD-based anonymity constraints. Uses partitioned equal-gain combining (P-EGC) scheme that leverages receiver diversity without requiring transmitter-specific CSI.
AI.result: Simulations show anonymity-reliability tradeoffs across different SNRs and data streams. Reveals opposite trends of anonymity with respect to transmitter-dependent noise variations in low-SNR vs high-SNR regimes.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enables transmitter anonymity at physical layer through signal design, balancing anonymity and communication reliability while revealing interesting noise-dependent anonymity behaviors.

title: Strategy-Supervised Autonomous Laparoscopic Camera Control via Event-Driven Graph Mining
comment: Submitted to IEEE Transactions on Robotics (T-RO). 19 pages, 9 figures
summary: Autonomous laparoscopic camera control must maintain a stable and safe surgical view under rapid tool-tissue interactions while remaining interpretable to surgeons. We present a strategy-grounded framework that couples high-level vision-language inference with low-level closed-loop control. Offline, raw surgical videos are parsed into camera-relevant temporal events (e.g., interaction, working-distance deviation, and view-quality degradation) and structured as attributed event graphs. Mining these graphs yields a compact set of reusable camera-handling strategy primitives, which provide structured supervision for learning. Online, a fine-tuned Vision-Language Model (VLM) processes the live laparoscopic view to predict the dominant strategy and discrete image-based motion commands, executed by an IBVS-RCM controller under strict safety constraints; optional speech input enables intuitive human-in-the-loop conditioning. On a surgeon-annotated dataset, event parsing achieves reliable temporal localization (F1-score 0.86), and the mined strategies show strong semantic alignment with expert interpretation (cluster purity 0.81). Extensive ex vivo experiments on silicone phantoms and porcine tissues demonstrate that the proposed system outperforms junior surgeons in standardized camera-handling evaluations, reducing field-of-view centering error by 35.26% and image shaking by 62.33%, while preserving smooth motion and stable working-distance regulation.

AI.tldr: A vision-language framework for autonomous laparoscopic camera control that learns surgical strategies from video data and executes them via closed-loop control, outperforming junior surgeons in camera-handling tasks.
AI.motivation: Autonomous laparoscopic camera control needs to maintain stable surgical views during rapid tool-tissue interactions while remaining interpretable to surgeons, requiring a system that can understand surgical context and execute appropriate camera movements.
AI.method: Offline: Parse surgical videos into camera-relevant temporal events and create attributed event graphs, then mine reusable camera-handling strategy primitives. Online: Use fine-tuned Vision-Language Model to predict dominant strategies and motion commands, executed by IBVS-RCM controller with safety constraints and optional speech input for human conditioning.
AI.result: Event parsing achieves F1-score 0.86 for temporal localization, mined strategies show cluster purity 0.81 with expert interpretation. Ex vivo experiments show 35.26% reduction in field-of-view centering error and 62.33% reduction in image shaking compared to junior surgeons, while maintaining smooth motion and stable working-distance regulation.
AI.conclusion: The strategy-grounded framework successfully couples high-level vision-language inference with low-level closed-loop control for autonomous laparoscopic camera assistance, demonstrating superior performance to junior surgeons while maintaining interpretability and safety.

title: gQIR: Generative Quanta Image Reconstruction
summary: Capturing high-quality images from only a few detected photons is a fundamental challenge in computational imaging. Single-photon avalanche diode (SPAD) sensors promise high-quality imaging in regimes where conventional cameras fail, but raw \emph{quanta frames} contain only sparse, noisy, binary photon detections. Recovering a coherent image from a burst of such frames requires handling alignment, denoising, and demosaicing (for color) under noise statistics far outside those assumed by standard restoration pipelines or modern generative models. We present an approach that adapts large text-to-image latent diffusion models to the photon-limited domain of quanta burst imaging. Our method leverages the structural and semantic priors of internet-scale diffusion models while introducing mechanisms to handle Bernoulli photon statistics. By integrating latent-space restoration with burst-level spatio-temporal reasoning, our approach produces reconstructions that are both photometrically faithful and perceptually pleasing, even under high-speed motion. We evaluate the method on synthetic benchmarks and new real-world datasets, including the first color SPAD burst dataset and a challenging \textit{Deforming (XD)} video benchmark. Across all settings, the approach substantially improves perceptual quality over classical and modern learning-based baselines, demonstrating the promise of adapting large generative priors to extreme photon-limited sensing. Code at \href{https://github.com/Aryan-Garg/gQIR}{https://github.com/Aryan-Garg/gQIR}.

AI.tldr: Adapts large text-to-image latent diffusion models to handle sparse, noisy binary photon detections from SPAD sensors, enabling high-quality image reconstruction from photon-limited quanta burst imaging.
AI.motivation: SPAD sensors can image in extreme low-light conditions where conventional cameras fail, but raw quanta frames contain only sparse, noisy binary photon detections. Standard restoration pipelines and modern generative models can't handle the unique Bernoulli photon statistics of this photon-limited domain.
AI.method: Adapts large text-to-image latent diffusion models to the photon-limited domain by leveraging their structural and semantic priors while introducing mechanisms to handle Bernoulli photon statistics. Integrates latent-space restoration with burst-level spatio-temporal reasoning.
AI.result: Produces reconstructions that are both photometrically faithful and perceptually pleasing, even under high-speed motion. Substantially improves perceptual quality over classical and modern learning-based baselines on synthetic benchmarks and new real-world datasets including first color SPAD burst dataset and Deforming (XD) video benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the promise of adapting large generative priors to extreme photon-limited sensing, enabling high-quality imaging from only a few detected photons by bridging internet-scale diffusion models with specialized photon statistics handling.

title: Physics-based phenomenological characterization of cross-modal bias in multimodal models
comment: Best Paper Award at BiasinAI track in AAAI2026
summary: The term 'algorithmic fairness' is used to evaluate whether AI models operate fairly in both comparative (where fairness is understood as formal equality, such as "treat like cases as like") and non-comparative (where unfairness arises from the model's inaccuracy, arbitrariness, or inscrutability) contexts. Recent advances in multimodal large language models (MLLMs) are breaking new ground in multimodal understanding, reasoning, and generation; however, we argue that inconspicuous distortions arising from complex multimodal interaction dynamics can lead to systematic bias. The purpose of this position paper is twofold: first, it is intended to acquaint AI researchers with phenomenological explainable approaches that rely on the physical entities that the machine experiences during training/inference, as opposed to the traditional cognitivist symbolic account or metaphysical approaches; second, it is to state that this phenomenological doctrine will be practically useful for tackling algorithmic fairness issues in MLLMs. We develop a surrogate physics-based model that describes transformer dynamics (i.e., semantic network structure and self-/cross-attention) to analyze the dynamics of cross-modal bias in MLLM, which are not fully captured by conventional embedding- or representation-level analyses. We support this position through multi-input diagnostic experiments: 1) perturbation-based analyses of emotion classification using Qwen2.5-Omni and Gemma 3n, and 2) dynamical analysis of Lorenz chaotic time-series prediction through the physical surrogate. Across two architecturally distinct MLLMs, we show that multimodal inputs can reinforce modality dominance rather than mitigate it, as revealed by structured error-attractor patterns under systematic label perturbation, complemented by dynamical analysis.

AI.tldr: This position paper argues that phenomenological approaches using physical surrogate models can better address algorithmic fairness in MLLMs by revealing cross-modal bias dynamics that traditional methods miss.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address algorithmic fairness issues in multimodal large language models (MLLMs), arguing that current approaches fail to capture inconspicuous distortions from complex multimodal interactions that lead to systematic bias.
AI.method: Develops a physics-based surrogate model to analyze transformer dynamics (semantic network structure and self-/cross-attention) and conducts multi-input diagnostic experiments: 1) perturbation-based emotion classification analysis using Qwen2.5-Omni and Gemma 3n, and 2) dynamical analysis of Lorenz chaotic time-series prediction.
AI.result: Shows that multimodal inputs can reinforce modality dominance rather than mitigate it, as revealed by structured error-attractor patterns under systematic label perturbation across two architecturally distinct MLLMs.
AI.conclusion: Phenomenological approaches using physical surrogate models provide practical utility for tackling algorithmic fairness in MLLMs by capturing cross-modal bias dynamics that conventional embedding- or representation-level analyses miss.

title: Continuous-Time Analysis of AFDM: Fundamental Bounds, and Effects of Pulse-Shaping and Hardware Impairments
summary: Affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM) has recently emerged as a resilient waveform candidate for high-mobility next-generation wireless systems. However, current literature mostly focuses on discrete time (DT) models, often overlooking effects and hardware non-idealities of actual continuous time (CT) signal generation. In this paper, we bridge this gap by developing a CT-analytical framework based on the affine Fourier series (AFS) representation, which allows us to demonstrate that strictly bandlimited pulses and subcarrier suppression strategies are essential to maintain the multicarrier structure of the signal. In addition, we derive the analytical power spectral density of AFDM and evaluate its spectral characteristics in comparison with other multicarrier schemes, considering the impact of realistic truncated pulse-shaping. Furthermore, we analyze the sensitivity of the CT model to phase noise, carrier frequency offset, and sampling jitter, providing a theoretical analysis of communication performance. Finally, we derive closed-form Cramér-Rao bounds for channel parameter estimation, showing that the chirped modulation peculiar of AFDM increases the estimation variance but enables the resolution of Doppler ambiguities. Our findings provide the necessary theoretical and practical foundations for the implementation of AFDM in realistic wireless transceivers.

AI.tldr: AFDM's CT framework reveals bandlimited pulses and subcarrier suppression are essential; spectral analysis shows AFDM's characteristics; sensitivity to hardware impairments analyzed; chirped modulation increases estimation variance but resolves Doppler ambiguities.
AI.motivation: Current AFDM literature focuses on discrete-time models, overlooking continuous-time signal generation effects and hardware non-idealities. This gap needs bridging for practical implementation in realistic wireless transceivers.
AI.method: Developed continuous-time analytical framework using affine Fourier series representation. Analyzed spectral characteristics, sensitivity to phase noise/CFO/sampling jitter, and derived Cramér-Rao bounds for channel parameter estimation.
AI.result: Bandlimited pulses and subcarrier suppression are essential for AFDM's multicarrier structure. AFDM's spectral characteristics differ from other schemes. Chirped modulation increases estimation variance but enables Doppler ambiguity resolution.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides necessary theoretical and practical foundations for AFDM implementation in realistic wireless transceivers, bridging the gap between discrete-time models and continuous-time signal generation realities.

title: Tensor Network Generator-Enhanced Optimization for Traveling Salesman Problem
summary: We present an application of the tensor network generator-enhanced optimization (TN-GEO) framework to address the traveling salesman problem (TSP), a fundamental combinatorial optimization challenge. Our approach employs a tensor network Born machine based on automatically differentiable matrix product states (MPS) as the generative model, using the Born rule to define probability distributions over candidate solutions. Unlike approaches based on binary encoding, which require $N^2$ variables and penalty terms to enforce valid tour constraints, we adopt a permutation-based formulation with integer variables and use autoregressive sampling with masking to guarantee that every generated sample is a valid tour by construction. We also introduce a $k$-site MPS variant that learns distributions over $k$-grams (consecutive city subsequences) using a sliding window approach, enabling parameter-efficient modeling for larger instances. Experimental validation on TSPLIB benchmark instances with up to 52 cities demonstrates that TN-GEO can outperform classical heuristics including swap and 2-opt hill-climbing. The $k$-site variants, which put more focus on local correlations, show better results compared to the full-MPS case.

AI.tldr: TN-GEO framework applies tensor network generative models to solve TSP using permutation-based formulation with autoregressive sampling and k-site MPS variants, outperforming classical heuristics on benchmark instances.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the traveling salesman problem (TSP), a fundamental combinatorial optimization challenge, aiming to develop more efficient approaches that avoid the complexity of binary encoding methods which require N² variables and penalty terms for constraint enforcement.
AI.method: Uses tensor network Born machine based on automatically differentiable matrix product states (MPS) as generative model. Adopts permutation-based formulation with integer variables and uses autoregressive sampling with masking to guarantee valid tours by construction. Introduces k-site MPS variant that learns distributions over k-grams using sliding window approach for parameter-efficient modeling of larger instances.
AI.result: Experimental validation on TSPLIB benchmark instances with up to 52 cities shows TN-GEO can outperform classical heuristics including swap and 2-opt hill-climbing. The k-site variants, which focus more on local correlations, show better results compared to the full-MPS case.
AI.conclusion: The TN-GEO framework provides an effective approach for solving TSP using tensor network generative models, with permutation-based formulation and k-site MPS variants offering improved performance and scalability over traditional methods.

title: Cell-Free Massive MIMO-Assisted SWIPT Using Stacked Intelligent Metasurfaces
summary: This study explores a next-generation multiple access (NGMA) framework for cell-free massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) systems enhanced by stacked intelligent metasurfaces (SIMs), aiming to improve simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) performance. A fundamental challenge lies in optimally selecting the operating modes of access points (APs) to jointly maximize the received energy and satisfy spectral efficiency (SE) quality-of-service constraints. Practical system impairments, including a non-linear harvested energy model, pilot contamination (PC), channel estimation errors, and reliance on long-term statistical channel state information (CSI), are considered. We derive closed-form expressions for both the achievable SE and the average sum harvested energy (sum-HE). A mixed-integer non-convex optimization problem is formulated to jointly optimize the SIM phase shifts, APs mode selection, and power allocation to maximize average sum-HE under SE and average harvested energy constraints. To solve this problem, we propose a centralized training, decentralized execution (CTDE) framework based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL), which efficiently handles high-dimensional decision spaces. A Markovian environment and a normalized joint reward function are introduced to enhance the training stability across on-policy and off-policy DRL algorithms. Additionally, we provide a two-phase convex-based solution as a theoretical robust performance. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed DRL-based CTDE framework achieves SWIPT performance comparable to convexification-based solution, while significantly outperforming baselines.

AI.tldr: NGMA framework for CF-mMIMO with SIMs to enhance SWIPT performance, using DRL-based CTDE to optimize SIM phase shifts, AP mode selection, and power allocation under practical impairments.
AI.motivation: Improve SWIPT performance in cell-free massive MIMO systems by addressing the challenge of optimal AP mode selection to jointly maximize received energy while satisfying spectral efficiency constraints, considering practical system impairments.
AI.method: Propose a CTDE framework based on DRL to solve mixed-integer non-convex optimization problem for SIM phase shifts, AP mode selection, and power allocation. Use Markovian environment and normalized joint reward for training stability. Also provide two-phase convex-based solution as theoretical benchmark.
AI.result: DRL-based CTDE achieves SWIPT performance comparable to convexification-based solution while significantly outperforming baselines. Closed-form expressions derived for achievable SE and average sum harvested energy.
AI.conclusion: The proposed DRL-based CTDE framework effectively handles high-dimensional decision spaces in NGMA CF-mMIMO systems with SIMs, providing robust SWIPT performance under practical impairments while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Conflict-Based Search for Multi-Agent Path Finding with Elevators
summary: This paper investigates a problem called Multi-Agent Path Finding with Elevators (MAPF-E), which seeks conflict-free paths for multiple agents from their start to goal locations that may locate on different floors, and the agents can use elevators to travel between floors. The existence of elevators complicates the interaction among the agents and introduces new challenges to the planning. On the one hand, elevators can cause many conflicts among the agents due to its relatively long traversal time across floors, especially when many agents need to reach a different floor. On the other hand, the planner has to reason in a larger state space including the states of the elevators, besides the locations of the agents.

AI.tldr: MAPF-E extends multi-agent path finding to include elevators for inter-floor movement, introducing new challenges in conflict resolution and state space complexity.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the practical need for multi-agent path planning in multi-floor environments where agents must use elevators to move between floors, which introduces complex interactions and conflicts not present in single-floor scenarios.
AI.method: The paper investigates MAPF-E as a problem formulation, focusing on conflict-free path planning for multiple agents across different floors using elevators, requiring reasoning about both agent locations and elevator states.
AI.result: The abstract identifies key challenges: elevators cause many conflicts due to long traversal times when many agents need floor changes, and planners must handle a larger state space including elevator states in addition to agent locations.
AI.conclusion: MAPF-E introduces significant new complexities to multi-agent path finding, requiring novel approaches to handle elevator-induced conflicts and the expanded state space for effective multi-floor planning.

title: MedCLIPSeg: Probabilistic Vision-Language Adaptation for Data-Efficient and Generalizable Medical Image Segmentation
summary: Medical image segmentation remains challenging due to limited annotations for training, ambiguous anatomical features, and domain shifts. While vision-language models such as CLIP offer strong cross-modal representations, their potential for dense, text-guided medical image segmentation remains underexplored. We present MedCLIPSeg, a novel framework that adapts CLIP for robust, data-efficient, and uncertainty-aware medical image segmentation. Our approach leverages patch-level CLIP embeddings through probabilistic cross-modal attention, enabling bidirectional interaction between image and text tokens and explicit modeling of predictive uncertainty. Together with a soft patch-level contrastive loss that encourages more nuanced semantic learning across diverse textual prompts, MedCLIPSeg effectively improves data efficiency and domain generalizability. Extensive experiments across 16 datasets spanning five imaging modalities and six organs demonstrate that MedCLIPSeg outperforms prior methods in accuracy, efficiency, and robustness, while providing interpretable uncertainty maps that highlight local reliability of segmentation results. This work demonstrates the potential of probabilistic vision-language modeling for text-driven medical image segmentation.

AI.tldr: MedCLIPSeg adapts CLIP for text-guided medical image segmentation using probabilistic cross-modal attention and uncertainty modeling, achieving better accuracy and data efficiency across diverse medical imaging datasets.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation faces challenges with limited annotations, ambiguous anatomical features, and domain shifts. Vision-language models like CLIP offer strong cross-modal representations but their potential for dense, text-guided medical segmentation remains underexplored.
AI.method: MedCLIPSeg leverages patch-level CLIP embeddings through probabilistic cross-modal attention for bidirectional image-text interaction and explicit uncertainty modeling. It uses a soft patch-level contrastive loss for nuanced semantic learning across diverse textual prompts.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across 16 datasets spanning five imaging modalities and six organs show MedCLIPSeg outperforms prior methods in accuracy, efficiency, and robustness, while providing interpretable uncertainty maps highlighting local segmentation reliability.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates the potential of probabilistic vision-language modeling for text-driven medical image segmentation, offering improved data efficiency and domain generalizability with uncertainty awareness.

title: When can we trust untrusted monitoring? A safety case sketch across collusion strategies
summary: AIs are increasingly being deployed with greater autonomy and capabilities, which increases the risk that a misaligned AI may be able to cause catastrophic harm. Untrusted monitoring -- using one untrusted model to oversee another -- is one approach to reducing risk. Justifying the safety of an untrusted monitoring deployment is challenging because developers cannot safely deploy a misaligned model to test their protocol directly. In this paper, we develop upon existing methods for rigorously demonstrating safety based on pre-deployment testing. We relax assumptions that previous AI control research made about the collusion strategies a misaligned AI might use to subvert untrusted monitoring. We develop a taxonomy covering passive self-recognition, causal collusion (hiding pre-shared signals), acausal collusion (hiding signals via Schelling points), and combined strategies. We create a safety case sketch to clearly present our argument, explicitly state our assumptions, and highlight unsolved challenges. We identify conditions under which passive self-recognition could be a more effective collusion strategy than those studied previously. Our work builds towards more robust evaluations of untrusted monitoring.

AI.tldr: The paper develops methods for rigorously demonstrating safety of untrusted monitoring systems by relaxing assumptions about AI collusion strategies and creating a taxonomy of potential subversion methods.
AI.motivation: As AIs gain more autonomy and capabilities, misaligned AIs pose increasing catastrophic risks. Untrusted monitoring (using one AI to oversee another) is a risk reduction approach, but justifying its safety is challenging because developers cannot safely deploy misaligned models for direct testing.
AI.method: The paper builds on existing pre-deployment testing methods, relaxes previous assumptions about AI collusion strategies, develops a taxonomy covering passive self-recognition, causal collusion (hiding pre-shared signals), acausal collusion (hiding signals via Schelling points), and combined strategies. Creates a safety case sketch to present arguments clearly and highlight assumptions.
AI.result: Identifies conditions under which passive self-recognition could be a more effective collusion strategy than those studied previously. The work builds towards more robust evaluations of untrusted monitoring systems.
AI.conclusion: The paper advances methods for rigorous safety demonstration of untrusted monitoring by addressing previously overlooked collusion strategies, providing a structured taxonomy, and highlighting remaining challenges in AI safety evaluation.

title: Synapse-Inspired Energy Networks: A Neuromorphic Approach to Microgrid Protection without Communication Links
comment: Accepted in principle at Communications Engineering (Nature Portfolio). Topical Collection: "Microgrids and Distributed Energy Systems". Final formatting revisions pending. 24 February 2026
summary: Traditional protection systems for microgrids, which rely on high fault currents and continuous communication, struggle to keep up with the changing dynamics and cybersecurity concerns of decentralized networks. In this study, we introduce a novel biologically inspired protection system based on neuromorphic principles, where each distributed energy resource (DER) functions as a simple neuron. These neurons process local changes in voltage, current signals, and converting them into spike patterns that represent the severity of disturbances. Just as neurons communicate via synapses in biological systems, we exploit transmission cables to coordinate between DERs, enabling them to share information and respond to faults collectively. Fault detection and circuit breaker activation are driven by a First-To-Spike (FTTS) mechanism, similar to the concept of traveling wave protection, but without needing GPS synchronization or communication links. A key innovation is the ability to use the timing of spikes to locally determine the nature of a fault, offering an intelligent, adaptive response to disturbances. Performance shows tripping latency of 10-58 ms, surpassing conventional relays and even traveling-wave methods (60 ms), while maintaining detection accuracy above 98% and spatial selectivity over 97%, enabling real-time, communication-free, scalable protection for plug-and-play microgrids.

AI.tldr: A neuromorphic protection system for microgrids uses DERs as neurons that process local signals into spike patterns, enabling communication-free fault detection via First-To-Spike mechanism with superior speed and accuracy.
AI.motivation: Traditional microgrid protection systems struggle with changing dynamics and cybersecurity concerns in decentralized networks, requiring continuous communication and high fault currents.
AI.method: Biologically inspired system where each DER functions as a neuron processing local voltage/current signals into spike patterns. Transmission cables coordinate between DERs like synapses. Fault detection uses First-To-Spike mechanism similar to traveling wave protection but without GPS or communication links.
AI.result: Tripping latency of 10-58 ms (surpassing conventional relays and traveling-wave methods at 60 ms), detection accuracy above 98%, spatial selectivity over 97%.
AI.conclusion: The neuromorphic approach enables real-time, communication-free, scalable protection for plug-and-play microgrids with intelligent, adaptive fault response.

title: MoBiQuant: Mixture-of-Bits Quantization for Token-Adaptive Elastic LLMs
summary: Changing runtime complexity on cloud and edge devices necessitates elastic large language model (LLM) deployment, where an LLM can be inferred with various quantization precisions based on available computational resources. However, it has been observed that the calibration parameters for quantization are typically linked to specific precisions, which presents challenges during elastic-precision calibration and precision switching at runtime. In this work, we attribute the source of varying calibration parameters to the varying token-level sensitivity caused by a precision-dependent outlier migration phenomenon.Motivated by this observation, we propose \texttt{MoBiQuant}, a novel Mixture-of-Bits quantization framework that adjusts weight precision for elastic LLM inference based on token sensitivity. Specifically, we propose the many-in-one recursive residual quantization that can iteratively reconstruct higher-precision weights and the token-aware router to dynamically select the number of residual bit slices. MoBiQuant enables smooth precision switching while improving generalization for the distribution of token outliers. Experimental results demonstrate that MoBiQuant exhibits strong elasticity, enabling it to match the performance of bit-specific calibrated PTQ on LLaMA3-8B without repeated calibration.

AI.tldr: MoBiQuant: A Mixture-of-Bits quantization framework for elastic LLM inference that adjusts weight precision based on token sensitivity, enabling smooth precision switching without repeated calibration.
AI.motivation: Cloud and edge devices need elastic LLM deployment with various quantization precisions, but current calibration parameters are precision-specific, causing challenges during elastic-precision calibration and runtime precision switching.
AI.method: Proposes MoBiQuant with two key components: 1) many-in-one recursive residual quantization that iteratively reconstructs higher-precision weights, and 2) token-aware router that dynamically selects the number of residual bit slices based on token sensitivity.
AI.result: MoBiQuant demonstrates strong elasticity, matching the performance of bit-specific calibrated PTQ on LLaMA3-8B without requiring repeated calibration for different precision levels.
AI.conclusion: MoBiQuant enables efficient elastic LLM inference with smooth precision switching by addressing the token-level sensitivity variations caused by precision-dependent outlier migration, eliminating the need for repeated calibration.

title: Optimal QAM Constellation for Over-the-Air Computation in the Presence of Heavy-Tailed Channel Noise
summary: Over-the-air computation (OAC) enables low-latency aggregation over multiple-access channels (MACs) by exploiting the superposition property of the wireless medium to compute functions efficiently in distributed networks. A critical but often overlooked challenge is that electromagnetic interference in practical radio channels frequently exhibits heavy-tailed behavior, causing strong impulsive noise that severely degrades computation performance. This work studies digital OAC with QAM-based signaling under heavy-tailed interference modeled by a Cauchy distribution (lacking a finite second moment). We seek QAM-like constellations that minimize the mean-squared error (MSE) of sum aggregation subject to an average-power constraint. The problem is formulated as a constrained optimization, whose solution yields unique optimality conditions. Numerical results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed design. Notably, the framework extends naturally to nomographic functions, broader constellation families, and alternative noise models.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes optimal QAM-like constellation designs for digital over-the-air computation under heavy-tailed Cauchy interference to minimize mean-squared error for sum aggregation.
AI.motivation: Over-the-air computation enables efficient distributed aggregation via wireless superposition, but practical heavy-tailed electromagnetic interference (modeled by Cauchy distribution) severely degrades performance, creating a need for robust constellation designs.
AI.method: Formulates a constrained optimization problem to find QAM-like constellations that minimize mean-squared error for sum aggregation under average-power constraints, deriving unique optimality conditions for the solution.
AI.result: Numerical results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed constellation design, showing improved performance under heavy-tailed interference conditions.
AI.conclusion: The framework successfully addresses heavy-tailed interference in digital OAC and extends naturally to nomographic functions, broader constellation families, and alternative noise models.

title: BFA++: Hierarchical Best-Feature-Aware Token Prune for Multi-View Vision Language Action Model
summary: Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have achieved significant breakthroughs by leveraging Large Vision Language Models (VLMs) to jointly interpret instructions and visual inputs. However, the substantial increase in visual tokens, particularly from multi-view inputs, poses serious challenges to real-time robotic manipulation. Existing acceleration techniques for VLMs, such as token pruning, often result in degraded performance when directly applied to VLA models, as they overlook the relationships between different views and fail to account for the dynamic and task-specific characteristics of robotic operation. To address this, we propose BFA++, a dynamic token pruning framework designed specifically for VLA models. BFA++ introduces a hierarchical pruning strategy guided by two-level importance predictors: an intra-view predictor highlights task-relevant regions within each image to suppress spatial noise, while an inter-view predictor identifies critical camera views throughout different manipulation phases to reduce cross-view redundancy. This design enables efficient token selection while preserving essential visual cues, resulting in improved computational efficiency and higher manipulation success rates. Evaluations on the RoboTwin benchmark and real-world robotic tasks demonstrate that BFA++ consistently outperforms existing methods. BFA++ improves the success rate by about 10% on both the π0 and RDT models, achieving speedup of 1.8X and 1.5X, respectively. Our results highlight that context-sensitive and task-aware token pruning serves as a more effective strategy than full visual processing, enabling faster inference and improved manipulation accuracy in real-world robotic systems.

AI.tldr: BFA++ is a dynamic token pruning framework for Vision-Language-Action models that uses hierarchical pruning with intra-view and inter-view predictors to reduce visual token overhead while maintaining manipulation performance.
AI.motivation: VLA models face real-time challenges due to excessive visual tokens from multi-view inputs. Existing token pruning methods degrade VLA performance because they ignore view relationships and task-specific robotic operation dynamics.
AI.method: Proposes BFA++ with hierarchical pruning: intra-view predictor identifies task-relevant regions within each image to suppress spatial noise, and inter-view predictor identifies critical camera views across manipulation phases to reduce cross-view redundancy.
AI.result: BFA++ improves success rates by ~10% on both π0 and RDT models, achieving 1.8X and 1.5X speedups respectively. Outperforms existing methods on RoboTwin benchmark and real-world robotic tasks.
AI.conclusion: Context-sensitive, task-aware token pruning is more effective than full visual processing for VLA models, enabling faster inference and improved manipulation accuracy in real-world robotic systems.

title: SceMoS: Scene-Aware 3D Human Motion Synthesis by Planning with Geometry-Grounded Tokens
summary: Synthesizing text-driven 3D human motion within realistic scenes requires learning both semantic intent ("walk to the couch") and physical feasibility (e.g., avoiding collisions). Current methods use generative frameworks that simultaneously learn high-level planning and low-level contact reasoning, and rely on computationally expensive 3D scene data such as point clouds or voxel occupancy grids. We propose SceMoS, a scene-aware motion synthesis framework that shows that structured 2D scene representations can serve as a powerful alternative to full 3D supervision in physically grounded motion synthesis. SceMoS disentangles global planning from local execution using lightweight 2D cues and relying on (1) a text-conditioned autoregressive global motion planner that operates on a bird's-eye-view (BEV) image rendered from an elevated corner of the scene, encoded with DINOv2 features, as the scene representation, and (2) a geometry-grounded motion tokenizer trained via a conditional VQ-VAE, that uses 2D local scene heightmap, thus embedding surface physics directly into a discrete vocabulary. This 2D factorization reaches an efficiency-fidelity trade-off: BEV semantics capture spatial layout and affordance for global reasoning, while local heightmaps enforce fine-grained physical adherence without full 3D volumetric reasoning. SceMoS achieves state-of-the-art motion realism and contact accuracy on the TRUMANS benchmark, reducing the number of trainable parameters for scene encoding by over 50%, showing that 2D scene cues can effectively ground 3D human-scene interaction.

AI.tldr: SceMoS uses 2D scene representations (BEV images and heightmaps) instead of 3D data for text-driven 3D human motion synthesis, achieving better efficiency and realism.
AI.motivation: Current methods for text-driven 3D human motion synthesis require computationally expensive 3D scene data (point clouds/voxel grids) and simultaneously learn high-level planning and low-level contact reasoning, which is inefficient.
AI.method: Two-stage framework: (1) Text-conditioned autoregressive global motion planner using DINOv2-encoded BEV images for spatial layout, (2) Geometry-grounded motion tokenizer using conditional VQ-VAE with 2D local heightmaps for physical adherence.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art motion realism and contact accuracy on TRUMANS benchmark while reducing trainable parameters for scene encoding by over 50% compared to 3D-based methods.
AI.conclusion: 2D scene representations (BEV semantics and local heightmaps) can effectively ground 3D human-scene interaction without full 3D supervision, offering an efficient alternative to 3D volumetric reasoning.

title: Identifying two piecewise linear additive value functions from anonymous preference information
summary: Eliciting a preference model involves asking a person, named decision-maker, a series of questions. We assume that these preferences can be represented by an additive value function. In this work, we query simultaneously two decision-makers in the aim to elicit their respective value functions. For each query we receive two answers, without noise, but without knowing which answer corresponds to which decision-maker.We propose an elicitation procedure that identifies the two preference models when the marginal value functions are piecewise linear with known breaking points.

AI.tldr: Simultaneous elicitation of two decision-makers' additive value functions from mixed responses without knowing which answer belongs to whom
AI.motivation: When eliciting preferences from multiple decision-makers simultaneously, responses get mixed without knowing which answer corresponds to which person, creating a challenging identification problem
AI.method: Proposes an elicitation procedure that identifies both preference models when marginal value functions are piecewise linear with known breaking points, using structured queries and mathematical analysis of the mixed responses
AI.result: The method successfully identifies both decision-makers' value functions despite the mixed response problem, assuming noiseless responses and known piecewise linear structure
AI.conclusion: Simultaneous preference elicitation for multiple decision-makers is feasible with appropriate mathematical modeling and structured queries, enabling efficient preference learning in multi-person scenarios

title: Timing Recovery and Sequence Detection for Integrate-and-Fire Time Encoding Receivers
comment: 6 pages, 3 figures, accepted in 2026 IEEE Wireless Communications and Networking Conference (WCNC 2026)
summary: Recent advances in neuromorphic signal processing have introduced time encoding machines as a promising alternative to conventional uniform sampling for low-power communication receivers. In this paradigm, analog signals are converted into event timings by an integrate-and-fire circuit, allowing information to be represented through spike times rather than amplitude samples. While event-driven sampling eliminates the need for a fixed-rate clock, receivers equipped with integrate-and-fire time encoding machines, called time encoding receivers, often assume perfect symbol synchronization, leaving the problem of symbol timing recovery unresolved. This paper presents a joint timing recovery and data detection framework for integrate-and-fire time encoding receivers. The log-likelihood function is derived to capture the dependence between firing times, symbol timing offset, and transmitted sequence, leading to a maximum likelihood formulation for joint timing estimation and sequence detection. A practical two-stage receiver is developed, consisting of a timing recovery algorithm followed by a zero-forcing detector. Simulation results demonstrate accurate symbol timing offset estimation and improved symbol error rate performance compared to existing time encoding receivers.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a joint timing recovery and data detection framework for integrate-and-fire time encoding receivers, solving the previously unresolved symbol synchronization problem in neuromorphic communication systems.
AI.motivation: Time encoding machines offer low-power alternatives to conventional sampling in neuromorphic signal processing, but existing receivers assume perfect symbol synchronization, leaving timing recovery as an unresolved problem that needs to be addressed for practical implementation.
AI.method: The authors derive a log-likelihood function capturing dependencies between firing times, symbol timing offset, and transmitted sequence, leading to a maximum likelihood formulation. They develop a practical two-stage receiver with timing recovery algorithm followed by zero-forcing detector.
AI.result: Simulation results demonstrate accurate symbol timing offset estimation and improved symbol error rate performance compared to existing time encoding receivers without timing recovery capabilities.
AI.conclusion: The proposed joint timing recovery and data detection framework successfully addresses the symbol synchronization problem in integrate-and-fire time encoding receivers, enabling more practical implementation of neuromorphic communication systems.

title: FedAvg-Based CTMC Hazard Model for Federated Bridge Deterioration Assessment
summary: Bridge periodic inspection records contain sensitive information about public infrastructure, making cross-organizational data sharing impractical under existing data governance constraints. We propose a federated framework for estimating a Continuous-Time Markov Chain (CTMC) hazard model of bridge deterioration, enabling municipalities to collaboratively train a shared benchmark model without transferring raw inspection records. Each User holds local inspection data and trains a log-linear hazard model over three deterioration-direction transitions -- Good$\to$Minor, Good$\to$Severe, and Minor$\to$Severe -- with covariates for bridge age, coastline distance, and deck area. Local optimization is performed via mini-batch stochastic gradient descent on the CTMC log-likelihood, and only a 12-dimensional pseudo-gradient vector is uploaded to a central server per communication round. The server aggregates User updates using sample-weighted Federated Averaging (FedAvg) with momentum and gradient clipping. All experiments in this paper are conducted on fully synthetic data generated from a known ground-truth parameter set with region-specific heterogeneity, enabling controlled evaluation of federated convergence behaviour. Simulation results across heterogeneous Users show consistent convergence of the average negative log-likelihood, with the aggregated gradient norm decreasing as User scale increases. Furthermore, the federated update mechanism provides a natural participation incentive: Users who register their local inspection datasets on a shared technical-standard platform receive in return the periodically updated global benchmark parameters -- information that cannot be obtained from local data alone -- thereby enabling evidence-based life-cycle planning without surrendering data sovereignty.

AI.tldr: Federated CTMC hazard model for bridge deterioration enables municipalities to collaboratively train benchmark models without sharing raw inspection data, using only aggregated pseudo-gradients.
AI.motivation: Bridge inspection records contain sensitive infrastructure data, making cross-organizational sharing impractical under current governance constraints. Municipalities need collaborative deterioration models without compromising data sovereignty.
AI.method: Federated framework where each user trains local log-linear CTMC hazard models for three deterioration transitions with covariates (age, coastline distance, deck area). Local optimization via mini-batch SGD on CTMC log-likelihood, uploading only 12D pseudo-gradients to server. Server aggregates using sample-weighted FedAvg with momentum and gradient clipping.
AI.result: Experiments on synthetic data show consistent convergence of average negative log-likelihood with decreasing gradient norm as user scale increases. Federated mechanism provides participation incentive: users get global benchmark parameters without surrendering local data.
AI.conclusion: The federated CTMC approach enables evidence-based bridge life-cycle planning through collaborative model training while preserving data sovereignty, offering a practical solution for infrastructure management under governance constraints.

title: Acoustic Feedback for Closed-Loop Force Control in Robotic Grinding
comment: Accepted to IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA) 2026. 8 pages, 10 figures
summary:
Acoustic feedback is a critical indicator for assessing the contact condition between the tool and the workpiece when humans perform grinding tasks with rotary tools. In contrast, robotic grinding systems typically rely on force sensing, with acoustic information largely ignored. This reliance on force sensors is costly and difficult to adapt to different grinding tools, whereas audio sensors (microphones) are low-cost and can be mounted on any medium that conducts grinding sound.
  This paper introduces a low-cost Acoustic Feedback Robotic Grinding System (AFRG) that captures audio signals with a contact microphone, estimates grinding force from the audio in real time, and enables closed-loop force control of the grinding process. Compared with conventional force-sensing approaches, AFRG achieves a 4-fold improvement in consistency across different grinding disc conditions. AFRG relies solely on a low-cost microphone, which is approximately 200-fold cheaper than conventional force sensors, as the sensing modality, providing an easily deployable, cost-effective robotic grinding solution.

AI.tldr: Low-cost acoustic feedback system replaces expensive force sensors for robotic grinding, using audio signals to estimate grinding force and achieve better consistency.
AI.motivation: Current robotic grinding systems rely on expensive force sensors that are costly and difficult to adapt to different tools, while humans naturally use acoustic feedback. Audio sensors are cheap and versatile but largely ignored in robotic systems.
AI.method: Developed Acoustic Feedback Robotic Grinding System (AFRG) that uses a contact microphone to capture audio signals, estimates grinding force from audio in real time, and implements closed-loop force control of the grinding process.
AI.result: AFRG achieves 4-fold improvement in consistency across different grinding disc conditions compared to conventional force-sensing approaches. The microphone-based system is approximately 200-fold cheaper than conventional force sensors.
AI.conclusion: AFRG provides a cost-effective, easily deployable robotic grinding solution that leverages low-cost acoustic sensing to replace expensive force sensors while improving process consistency.

title: Path-Decoupled Hyperbolic Flow Matching for Few-Shot Adaptation
summary: Recent advances in cross-modal few-shot adaptation treat visual-semantic alignment as a continuous feature transport problem via Flow Matching (FM). However, we argue that Euclidean-based FM overlooks fundamental limitations of flat geometry, where polynomial volume growth fails to accommodate diverse feature distributions, leading to severe path entanglement. To this end, we propose path-decoupled Hyperbolic Flow Matching (HFM), leveraging the Lorentz manifold's exponential expansion for trajectory decoupling. HFM structures the transport via two key designs: 1) Centripetal hyperbolic alignment: It constructs a centripetal hierarchy by anchoring textual roots, which pushes visual leaves to the boundary to initialize orderly flows. 2) Path-decoupled objective: It acts as a ``semantic guardrail'' rigidly confining trajectories within isolated class-specific geodesic corridors via step-wise supervision. Furthermore, we devise an adaptive diameter-based stopping to prevent over-transportation into the crowded origin based on the intrinsic semantic scale. Extensive ablations on 11 benchmarks have shown that HFM establishes a new state-of-the-art, consistently outperforming its Euclidean counterparts. Our codes and models will be released.

AI.tldr: HFM introduces hyperbolic flow matching for cross-modal few-shot adaptation, using Lorentz manifold geometry to decouple feature transport paths and prevent entanglement, achieving SOTA results.
AI.motivation: Euclidean-based Flow Matching fails to handle diverse feature distributions due to flat geometry limitations, causing path entanglement in cross-modal few-shot adaptation.
AI.method: Path-decoupled Hyperbolic Flow Matching (HFM) with: 1) Centripetal hyperbolic alignment anchoring textual roots to push visual leaves to boundary; 2) Path-decoupled objective confining trajectories within class-specific geodesic corridors; 3) Adaptive diameter-based stopping.
AI.result: HFM establishes new state-of-the-art on 11 benchmarks, consistently outperforming Euclidean counterparts in cross-modal few-shot adaptation.
AI.conclusion: Hyperbolic geometry provides superior feature transport for cross-modal adaptation by enabling path decoupling and preventing entanglement, with HFM demonstrating significant performance improvements.

title: Grounding LLMs in Scientific Discovery via Embodied Actions
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown significant potential in scientific discovery but struggle to bridge the gap between theoretical reasoning and verifiable physical simulation. Existing solutions operate in a passive "execute-then-response" loop and thus lacks runtime perception, obscuring agents to transient anomalies (e.g., numerical instability or diverging oscillations). To address this limitation, we propose EmbodiedAct, a framework that transforms established scientific software into active embodied agents by grounding LLMs in embodied actions with a tight perception-execution loop. We instantiate EmbodiedAct within MATLAB and evaluate it on complex engineering design and scientific modeling tasks. Extensive experiments show that EmbodiedAct significantly outperforms existing baselines, achieving SOTA performance by ensuring satisfactory reliability and stability in long-horizon simulations and enhanced accuracy in scientific modeling.

AI.tldr: EmbodiedAct transforms scientific software into active embodied agents by grounding LLMs in embodied actions with tight perception-execution loops, outperforming existing baselines on complex engineering and scientific tasks.
AI.motivation: LLMs show potential in scientific discovery but struggle to bridge theoretical reasoning with verifiable physical simulation. Existing solutions use passive "execute-then-response" loops that lack runtime perception, preventing agents from detecting transient anomalies like numerical instability or diverging oscillations.
AI.method: EmbodiedAct transforms established scientific software into active embodied agents by grounding LLMs in embodied actions with a tight perception-execution loop. The framework is instantiated within MATLAB to enable runtime perception and active intervention during simulations.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show EmbodiedAct significantly outperforms existing baselines, achieving state-of-the-art performance by ensuring satisfactory reliability and stability in long-horizon simulations and enhanced accuracy in scientific modeling.
AI.conclusion: EmbodiedAct successfully addresses the limitation of passive LLM-based scientific tools by creating active embodied agents that can perceive and respond to runtime anomalies, enabling more reliable and accurate scientific simulations and engineering design.

title: Controllable Exploration in Hybrid-Policy RLVR for Multi-Modal Reasoning
comment: Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2026
summary: Reinforcement Learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) has emerged as a primary learning paradigm for enhancing the reasoning capabilities of multi-modal large language models (MLLMs). However, during RL training, the enormous state space of MLLM and sparse rewards often leads to entropy collapse, policy degradation, or over-exploitation of suboptimal behaviors. This necessitates an exploration strategy that maintains productive stochasticity while avoiding the drawbacks of uncontrolled random sampling, yielding inefficient exploration. In this paper, we propose CalibRL, a hybrid-policy RLVR framework that supports controllable exploration with expert guidance, enabled by two key mechanisms. First, a distribution-aware advantage weighting scales updates by group rareness to calibrate the distribution, therefore preserving exploration. Meanwhile, the asymmetric activation function (LeakyReLU) leverages the expert knowledge as a calibration baseline to moderate overconfident updates while preserving their corrective direction. CalibRL increases policy entropy in a guided manner and clarifies the target distribution by estimating the on-policy distribution through online sampling. Updates are driven by these informative behaviors, avoiding convergence to erroneous patterns. Importantly, these designs help alleviate the distributional mismatch between the model's policy and expert trajectories, thereby achieving a more stable balance between exploration and exploitation. Extensive experiments across eight benchmarks, including both in-domain and out-of-domain settings, demonstrate consistent improvements, validating the effectiveness of our controllable hybrid-policy RLVR training. Code is available at https://github.com/zhh6425/CalibRL.

AI.tldr: CalibRL is a hybrid-policy RLVR framework that enables controllable exploration with expert guidance to prevent entropy collapse and policy degradation in MLLM training.
AI.motivation: RLVR training for MLLMs suffers from entropy collapse, policy degradation, and over-exploitation of suboptimal behaviors due to enormous state space and sparse rewards, requiring better exploration strategies.
AI.method: Uses distribution-aware advantage weighting to scale updates by group rareness, and asymmetric activation (LeakyReLU) to leverage expert knowledge as calibration baseline, enabling guided exploration while estimating on-policy distribution through online sampling.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across eight benchmarks (in-domain and out-of-domain) show consistent improvements, validating the effectiveness of controllable hybrid-policy RLVR training.
AI.conclusion: CalibRL achieves more stable balance between exploration and exploitation by alleviating distributional mismatch between model's policy and expert trajectories through guided exploration mechanisms.

title: Robot Local Planner: A Periodic Sampling-Based Motion Planner with Minimal Waypoints for Home Environments
comment: Accepted to IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA) 2025. Project Page: https://toyotafrc.github.io/RobotLocalPlanner-Proj/
summary: The objective of this study is to enable fast and safe manipulation tasks in home environments.
