Specifically, we aim to develop a system that can recognize its surroundings and identify target objects while in motion, enabling it to plan and execute actions accordingly. We propose a periodic sampling-based whole-body trajectory planning method, called the "Robot Local Planner (RLP)." This method leverages unique features of home environments to enhance computational efficiency, motion optimality, and robustness against recognition and control errors, all while ensuring safety. The RLP minimizes computation time by planning with minimal waypoints and generating safe trajectories. Furthermore, overall motion optimality is improved by periodically executing trajectory planning to select more optimal motions. This approach incorporates inverse kinematics that are robust to base position errors, further enhancing robustness. Evaluation experiments demonstrated that the RLP outperformed existing methods in terms of motion planning time, motion duration, and robustness, confirming its effectiveness in home environments. Moreover, application experiments using a tidy-up task achieved high success rates and short operation times, thereby underscoring its practical feasibility.

AI.tldr: Proposes Robot Local Planner (RLP) - a periodic sampling-based whole-body trajectory planning method for fast, safe manipulation in home environments that optimizes computation time, motion duration, and robustness.
AI.motivation: Enable fast and safe manipulation tasks in home environments by developing a system that can recognize surroundings and identify target objects while in motion, allowing for real-time planning and execution of actions.
AI.method: Periodic sampling-based whole-body trajectory planning method (RLP) that leverages home environment features to enhance efficiency. Uses minimal waypoints for faster computation, periodic replanning for optimal motion selection, and incorporates inverse kinematics robust to base position errors.
AI.result: RLP outperformed existing methods in motion planning time, motion duration, and robustness. Application experiments with tidy-up tasks achieved high success rates and short operation times, demonstrating practical feasibility.
AI.conclusion: The RLP method effectively enables fast and safe manipulation in home environments by balancing computational efficiency, motion optimality, and robustness, with practical validation through successful tidy-up tasks.

title: Pip-Stereo: Progressive Iterations Pruner for Iterative Optimization based Stereo Matching
summary: While iterative stereo matching achieves high accuracy, its dependence on Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) hinders edge deployment, a challenge underexplored in existing researches. We analyze iterative refinement and reveal that disparity updates are spatially sparse and temporally redundant. First, we introduce a progressive iteration pruning strategy that suppresses redundant update steps, effectively collapsing the recursive computation into a near-single-pass inference. Second, we propose a collaborative monocular prior transfer framework that implicitly embeds depth priors without requiring a dedicated monocular encoder, thereby eliminating its associated computational burden. Third, we develop FlashGRU, a hardware-aware RNN operator leveraging structured sparsity and I/O-conscious design, achieving a 7.28$\times$ speedup, 76.6\% memory peak reduction and 80.9\% global memory requests reduction over natvie ConvGRUs under 2K resolution. Our PipStereo enables real-time, high-fidelity stereo matching on edge hardware: it processes 320$\times$640 frames in just 75ms on an NVIDIA Jetson Orin NX (FP16) and 19ms on RTX 4090, matching the accuracy of large iterative based models, and our generalization ability and accuracy far exceeds that of existing real-time methods. Our embedded AI projects will be updated at: https://github.com/XPENG-Aridge-AI.

AI.tldr: PipStereo enables real-time stereo matching on edge hardware by pruning redundant iterations, eliminating monocular encoder overhead, and optimizing RNN operations, achieving 75ms inference on Jetson Orin NX while matching large model accuracy.
AI.motivation: Existing iterative stereo matching methods rely heavily on RNNs, making them unsuitable for edge deployment due to computational constraints. The spatial sparsity and temporal redundancy in disparity updates present optimization opportunities that haven't been fully explored.
AI.method: Three key innovations: 1) Progressive iteration pruning to collapse recursive computation into near-single-pass inference by suppressing redundant update steps; 2) Collaborative monocular prior transfer framework that embeds depth priors implicitly without dedicated encoder; 3) FlashGRU, a hardware-aware RNN operator using structured sparsity and I/O-conscious design.
AI.result: Achieves 7.28× speedup, 76.6% memory peak reduction, and 80.9% global memory requests reduction over native ConvGRUs at 2K resolution. Processes 320×640 frames in 75ms on NVIDIA Jetson Orin NX (FP16) and 19ms on RTX 4090, matching accuracy of large iterative models while far exceeding existing real-time methods in generalization and accuracy.
AI.conclusion: PipStereo successfully enables real-time, high-fidelity stereo matching on edge hardware by addressing the computational bottlenecks of iterative refinement through intelligent pruning, prior transfer, and hardware-aware optimization, making high-accuracy stereo vision practical for embedded applications.

title: Recursive Belief Vision Language Model
summary: Current vision-language-action (VLA) models struggle with long-horizon manipulation under partial observability. Most existing approaches remain observation-driven, relying on short context windows or repeated queries to vision-language models (VLMs). This leads to loss of task progress, action repetition under perceptual aliasing, and high inference latency. Semantic reasoning alone is not the primary bottleneck in long-horizon manipulation. Instead, VLAs lack persistent, action-conditioned state representations and exhibit limited temporal and physical reasoning, making them ill-suited for multi-stage control. This paper introduces RB-VLA, a belief-centric architecture trained with self-supervised world-model objectives that maintains a compact latent state encoding task-relevant history, dynamics, and object interactions. Queried once for high-level intent, the VLM provides task specification, while the belief tracks task progress and enables phase-aware, causally grounded control under partial observability without storing raw observations or scaling memory with time. The belief and intent jointly condition a diffusion policy for robust closed-loop execution. RB-VLA outperforms prior VLAs on long-horizon benchmarks, achieving 52.5% and 37.5% higher success on multi-stage pick-and-place and stacking tasks, respectively, compared to π0. It also reduces inference latency by up to 5x relative to baselines and eliminates memory growth across timesteps observed in existing VLAs. Ablations show that the belief module is the primary driver of performance, increasing success rates from 32.5% to 77.5%. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of belief-based state representations for long-horizon VLA policies.

AI.tldr: RB-VLA introduces a belief-centric architecture for long-horizon manipulation that maintains compact latent state representations, outperforming prior VLAs with 52.5-37.5% higher success rates and 5x lower latency.
AI.motivation: Current VLA models struggle with long-horizon manipulation under partial observability due to reliance on short context windows, repeated VLM queries, and lack of persistent action-conditioned state representations, leading to task progress loss, action repetition, and high latency.
AI.method: RB-VLA uses a belief-centric architecture with self-supervised world-model objectives that maintains a compact latent state encoding task history, dynamics, and object interactions. The VLM provides task specification once, while the belief tracks progress and enables phase-aware control under partial observability without storing raw observations.
AI.result: Outperforms prior VLAs with 52.5% higher success on multi-stage pick-and-place and 37.5% higher success on stacking tasks vs π0, reduces inference latency by up to 5x, eliminates memory growth across timesteps, and belief module increases success rates from 32.5% to 77.5%.
AI.conclusion: Belief-based state representations are effective for long-horizon VLA policies, addressing limitations of observation-driven approaches through persistent, action-conditioned state tracking that enables robust closed-loop execution under partial observability.

title: IMOVNO+: A Regional Partitioning and Meta-Heuristic Ensemble Framework for Imbalanced Multi-Class Learning
summary: Class imbalance, overlap, and noise degrade data quality, reduce model reliability, and limit generalization. Although widely studied in binary classification, these issues remain underexplored in multi-class settings, where complex inter-class relationships make minority-majority structures unclear and traditional clustering fails to capture distribution shape. Approaches that rely only on geometric distances risk removing informative samples and generating low-quality synthetic data, while binarization approaches treat imbalance locally and ignore global inter-class dependencies. At the algorithmic level, ensembles struggle to integrate weak classifiers, leading to limited robustness. This paper proposes IMOVNO+ (IMbalance-OVerlap-NOise+ Algorithm-Level Optimization), a two-level framework designed to jointly enhance data quality and algorithmic robustness for binary and multi-class tasks. At the data level, first, conditional probability is used to quantify the informativeness of each sample. Second, the dataset is partitioned into core, overlapping, and noisy regions. Third, an overlapping-cleaning algorithm is introduced that combines Z-score metrics with a big-jump gap distance. Fourth, a smart oversampling algorithm based on multi-regularization controls synthetic sample proximity, preventing new overlaps. At the algorithmic level, a meta-heuristic prunes ensemble classifiers to reduce weak-learner influence. IMOVNO+ was evaluated on 35 datasets (13 multi-class, 22 binary). Results show consistent superiority over state-of-the-art methods, approaching 100% in several cases. For multi-class data, IMOVNO+ achieves gains of 37-57% in G-mean, 25-44% in F1-score, 25-39% in precision, and 26-43% in recall. In binary tasks, it attains near-perfect performance with improvements of 14-39%. The framework handles data scarcity and imbalance from collection and privacy limits.

AI.tldr: IMOVNO+ is a two-level framework that addresses class imbalance, overlap, and noise in both binary and multi-class classification by combining data-level cleaning/oversampling with algorithmic-level ensemble pruning.
AI.motivation: Class imbalance, overlap, and noise degrade data quality and model reliability, especially in multi-class settings where traditional methods fail to capture complex inter-class relationships and binarization approaches ignore global dependencies.
AI.method: Two-level framework: (1) Data level: uses conditional probability to quantify sample informativeness, partitions dataset into core/overlapping/noisy regions, introduces overlapping-cleaning algorithm with Z-score and big-jump gap distance, and smart oversampling with multi-regularization controls. (2) Algorithm level: meta-heuristic prunes ensemble classifiers to reduce weak-learner influence.
AI.result: Evaluated on 35 datasets (13 multi-class, 22 binary). Shows consistent superiority over state-of-the-art methods, approaching 100% performance in several cases. Multi-class: 37-57% gains in G-mean, 25-44% in F1-score, 25-39% in precision, 26-43% in recall. Binary: 14-39% improvements with near-perfect performance.
AI.conclusion: IMOVNO+ effectively handles data scarcity and imbalance arising from collection and privacy limitations, providing a comprehensive solution for both binary and multi-class classification problems with complex data quality issues.

title: IG-RFT: An Interaction-Guided RL Framework for VLA Models in Long-Horizon Robotic Manipulation
summary: Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have demonstrated significant potential for generalist robotic policies; however, they struggle to generalize to long-horizon complex tasks in novel real-world domains due to distribution shifts and the scarcity of high-quality demonstrations. Although reinforcement learning (RL) offers a promising avenue for policy improvement, applying it to real-world VLA fine-tuning faces challenges regarding exploration efficiency, training stability, and sample cost. To address these issues, we propose IG-RFT, a novel Interaction-Guided Reinforced Fine-Tuning system designed for flow-based VLA models. Firstly, to facilitate effective policy optimization, we introduce Interaction-Guided Advantage Weighted Regression (IG-AWR), an RL algorithm that dynamically modulates exploration intensity based on the robot's interaction status. Furthermore, to address the limitations of sparse or task-specific rewards, we design a novel hybrid dense reward function that integrates the trajectory-level reward and the subtask-level reward. Finally, we construct a three-stage RL system comprising SFT, Offline RL, and Human-in-the-Loop RL for fine-tuning VLA models. Extensive real-world experiments on four challenging long-horizon tasks demonstrate that IG-RFT achieves an average success rate of 85.0%, significantly outperforming SFT (18.8%) and standard Offline RL baselines (40.0%). Ablation studies confirm the critical contributions of IG-AWR and hybrid reward shaping. In summary, our work establishes and validates a novel reinforced fine-tuning system for VLA models in real-world robotic manipulation.

AI.tldr: IG-RFT: A novel Interaction-Guided Reinforced Fine-Tuning system for VLA models that improves real-world robotic manipulation through dynamic exploration control and hybrid reward shaping.
AI.motivation: VLA models struggle with long-horizon complex tasks in novel real-world domains due to distribution shifts and scarcity of high-quality demonstrations. While RL offers potential for policy improvement, real-world VLA fine-tuning faces challenges with exploration efficiency, training stability, and sample cost.
AI.method: Proposes IG-RFT with three key components: 1) IG-AWR (Interaction-Guided Advantage Weighted Regression) that dynamically modulates exploration based on robot interaction status, 2) hybrid dense reward function combining trajectory-level and subtask-level rewards, and 3) three-stage RL system (SFT, Offline RL, Human-in-the-Loop RL) for fine-tuning VLA models.
AI.result: Achieves 85.0% average success rate on four challenging long-horizon real-world tasks, significantly outperforming SFT (18.8%) and standard Offline RL baselines (40.0%). Ablation studies confirm critical contributions of IG-AWR and hybrid reward shaping.
AI.conclusion: Establishes and validates a novel reinforced fine-tuning system for VLA models in real-world robotic manipulation, addressing key challenges of exploration efficiency, training stability, and sample cost through interaction-guided RL and hybrid reward design.

title: LESA: Learnable Stage-Aware Predictors for Diffusion Model Acceleration
summary: Diffusion models have achieved remarkable success in image and video generation tasks. However, the high computational demands of Diffusion Transformers (DiTs) pose a significant challenge to their practical deployment. While feature caching is a promising acceleration strategy, existing methods based on simple reusing or training-free forecasting struggle to adapt to the complex, stage-dependent dynamics of the diffusion process, often resulting in quality degradation and failing to maintain consistency with the standard denoising process. To address this, we propose a LEarnable Stage-Aware (LESA) predictor framework based on two-stage training. Our approach leverages a Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) to accurately learn temporal feature mappings from data. We further introduce a multi-stage, multi-expert architecture that assigns specialized predictors to different noise-level stages, enabling more precise and robust feature forecasting. Extensive experiments show our method achieves significant acceleration while maintaining high-fidelity generation. Experiments demonstrate 5.00x acceleration on FLUX.1-dev with minimal quality degradation (1.0% drop), 6.25x speedup on Qwen-Image with a 20.2% quality improvement over the previous SOTA (TaylorSeer), and 5.00x acceleration on HunyuanVideo with a 24.7% PSNR improvement over TaylorSeer. State-of-the-art performance on both text-to-image and text-to-video synthesis validates the effectiveness and generalization capability of our training-based framework across different models. Our code is included in the supplementary materials and will be released on GitHub.

AI.tldr: LESA predictor framework accelerates Diffusion Transformers using learnable stage-aware feature forecasting with KAN networks and multi-expert architecture, achieving 5-6x speedup with minimal quality degradation.
AI.motivation: Diffusion Transformers (DiTs) have high computational demands that hinder practical deployment. Existing feature caching methods struggle with complex, stage-dependent diffusion dynamics, causing quality degradation and inconsistency with standard denoising processes.
AI.method: Proposes LEarnable Stage-Aware (LESA) predictor framework with two-stage training: 1) Uses Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) to learn temporal feature mappings from data, 2) Introduces multi-stage, multi-expert architecture with specialized predictors for different noise-level stages.
AI.result: Achieves 5.00x acceleration on FLUX.1-dev with only 1.0% quality drop, 6.25x speedup on Qwen-Image with 20.2% quality improvement over SOTA, and 5.00x acceleration on HunyuanVideo with 24.7% PSNR improvement over TaylorSeer.
AI.conclusion: LESA framework effectively accelerates diffusion models while maintaining high-fidelity generation, demonstrating superior performance and generalization across text-to-image and text-to-video synthesis tasks compared to existing methods.

title: How Foundational Skills Influence VLM-based Embodied Agents:A Native Perspective
summary: Recent advances in vision-language models (VLMs) have shown promise for human-level embodied intelligence. However, existing benchmarks for VLM-driven embodied agents often rely on high-level commands or discretized action spaces, which are non-native settings that differ markedly from real-world control. In addition, current benchmarks focus primarily on high-level tasks and lack joint evaluation and analysis at both low and high levels. To address these limitations, we present NativeEmbodied, a challenging benchmark for VLM-driven embodied agents that uses a unified, native low-level action space. Built on diverse simulated scenes, NativeEmbodied includes three representative high-level tasks in complex scenarios to evaluate overall performance. For more detailed analysis, we further decouple the skills required by complex tasks and construct four types of low-level tasks, each targeting a fundamental embodied skill. This joint evaluation across task and skill granularities enables fine-grained assessment of embodied agents. Experiments with state-of-the-art VLMs reveal clear deficiencies in several fundamental embodied skills, and further analysis shows that these bottlenecks significantly limit performance on high-level tasks. NativeEmbodied highlights key challenges for current VLM-driven embodied agents and provides insights to guide future research.

AI.tldr: NativeEmbodied is a benchmark for vision-language model embodied agents using unified low-level action space, evaluating both high-level tasks and fundamental skills to identify VLM limitations.
AI.motivation: Existing VLM benchmarks use non-native settings (high-level commands, discretized actions) that differ from real-world control, and lack joint evaluation at both low and high skill levels.
AI.method: Built on diverse simulated scenes with unified native low-level action space. Includes three high-level tasks for overall performance, plus four low-level tasks targeting fundamental embodied skills for fine-grained analysis.
AI.result: Experiments with state-of-the-art VLMs reveal clear deficiencies in fundamental embodied skills, and analysis shows these bottlenecks significantly limit high-level task performance.
AI.conclusion: NativeEmbodied highlights key challenges for current VLM-driven embodied agents and provides insights to guide future research toward more capable embodied AI systems.

title: Distributed Continuous Aperture Arrays for Multiuser SWIPT
comment: The paper has been accepted for presentation at IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC), 24 to 28 May 2026
summary: This paper proposes a distributed continuous aperture array (D CAPA) to support simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) to multiple information users (IUs) and energy users (EUs). Each metasurface supports continuous surface currents that radiate electromagnetic (EM) waves for information and energy transmission to the users. These waves propagate through continuous EM channels characterized by the dyadic Green function. We formulate a system power consumption (PC) minimization problem subject to spectral efficiency and energy harvesting quality of service (QoS) requirements, where the QoS requirements are derived under the equal power allocation (EPA) scheme. An efficient two layer optimization algorithm is developed to solve this problem by optimizing the power allocation subject to the QoS violation penalties using augmented Lagrangian transformation. Our numerical results show that well optimized current distributions over each metasurface in the proposed D CAPA achieve up to 65% and 61% reductions in overall system PC compared to the EPA and colocated CAPA (C CAPA) cases, while maintaining the same total aperture size and transmission power.

AI.tldr: Distributed continuous aperture array (D CAPA) for SWIPT reduces system power consumption by 65% vs EPA and 61% vs colocated CAPA through optimized current distributions.
AI.motivation: To support simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) to multiple users efficiently, addressing the need for reduced power consumption while maintaining quality of service for both information and energy users.
AI.method: Proposes distributed continuous aperture array (D CAPA) with metasurfaces supporting continuous surface currents. Formulates power consumption minimization problem with spectral efficiency and energy harvesting QoS constraints. Develops two-layer optimization algorithm using augmented Lagrangian transformation to optimize power allocation with QoS violation penalties.
AI.result: Optimized current distributions achieve 65% reduction in system power consumption compared to equal power allocation (EPA) and 61% reduction compared to colocated CAPA (C CAPA), while maintaining same total aperture size and transmission power.
AI.conclusion: D CAPA with optimized current distributions significantly outperforms both EPA and colocated CAPA in power efficiency for SWIPT systems, demonstrating the importance of distributed architecture and careful optimization for simultaneous information and power transfer.

title: Golden Layers and Where to Find Them: Improved Knowledge Editing for Large Language Models Via Layer Gradient Analysis
summary: Knowledge editing in Large Language Models (LLMs) aims to update the model's prediction for a specific query to a desired target while preserving its behavior on all other inputs. This process typically involves two stages: identifying the layer to edit and performing the parameter update. Intuitively, different queries may localize knowledge at different depths of the model, resulting in different sample-wise editing performance for a fixed editing layer. In this work, we hypothesize the existence of fixed golden layers that can achieve near-optimal editing performance similar to sample-wise optimal layers. To validate this hypothesis, we provide empirical evidence by comparing golden layers against ground-truth sample-wise optimal layers. Furthermore, we show that golden layers can be reliably identified using a proxy dataset and generalize effectively to unseen test set queries across datasets. Finally, we propose a novel method, namely Layer Gradient Analysis (LGA) that estimates golden layers efficiently via gradient-attribution, avoiding extensive trial-and-error across multiple editing runs. Extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of our LGA approach across different LLM types and various knowledge editing methods.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Layer Gradient Analysis (LGA), a method to identify fixed "golden layers" in LLMs that achieve near-optimal knowledge editing performance across different queries, avoiding the need for sample-wise layer selection.
AI.motivation: Current knowledge editing in LLMs requires identifying optimal editing layers for each specific query, which is inefficient. The authors hypothesize that fixed "golden layers" exist that can achieve near-optimal editing performance similar to sample-wise optimal layers, eliminating the need for per-query layer selection.
AI.method: The paper proposes Layer Gradient Analysis (LGA), which uses gradient-attribution to efficiently estimate golden layers without extensive trial-and-error. LGA analyzes gradient patterns to identify layers that consistently achieve good editing performance across different queries.
AI.result: Empirical evidence shows golden layers exist and achieve near-optimal performance compared to ground-truth sample-wise optimal layers. Golden layers identified using proxy datasets generalize effectively to unseen test queries across different datasets. LGA demonstrates effectiveness and robustness across various LLM types and knowledge editing methods.
AI.conclusion: Fixed golden layers exist in LLMs for knowledge editing, and LGA provides an efficient gradient-based method to identify them, eliminating the need for expensive sample-wise layer selection while maintaining near-optimal editing performance.

title: Visual Cooperative Drone Tracking for Open-Path Gas Measurements
summary: Open-path Tunable Diode Laser Absorption Spectroscopy offers an effective method for measuring, mapping, and monitoring gas concentrations, such as leaking CO2 or methane. Compared to spatial sampling of gas distributions using in-situ sensors, open-path sensors in combination with gas tomography algorithms can cover large outdoor environments faster in a non-invasive way. However, the requirement of a dedicated reflection surface for the open-path laser makes automating the spatial sampling process challenging. This publication presents a robotic system for collecting open-path measurements, making use of a sensor mounted on a ground-based pan-tilt unit and a small drone carrying a reflector. By means of a zoom camera, the ground unit visually tracks red LED markers mounted on the drone and aligns the sensor's laser beam with the reflector. Incorporating GNSS position information provided by the drone's flight controller further improves the tracking approach. Outdoor experiments validated the system's performance, demonstrating successful autonomous tracking and valid CO2 measurements at distances up to 60 meters. Furthermore, the system successfully measured a CO2 plume without interference from the drone's propulsion system, demonstrating its superiority compared to flying in-situ sensors.

AI.tldr: Robotic system uses ground-based laser sensor and drone-carried reflector for autonomous open-path gas measurements up to 60m, overcoming reflection surface limitations.
AI.motivation: Open-path TDLAS requires dedicated reflection surfaces, making automated spatial sampling challenging. Need for non-invasive, large-area gas monitoring without fixed infrastructure.
AI.method: Ground-based pan-tilt unit with laser sensor and zoom camera tracks drone-mounted reflector using visual LED markers and GNSS positioning. Drone carries reflector, enabling flexible measurement paths.
AI.result: System successfully tracked autonomously up to 60m distance, collected valid CO2 measurements, and measured CO2 plumes without drone propulsion interference.
AI.conclusion: Robotic open-path TDLAS system enables automated, flexible gas monitoring superior to flying in-situ sensors, with practical outdoor validation.

title: Probing and Bridging Geometry-Interaction Cues for Affordance Reasoning in Vision Foundation Models
summary: What does it mean for a visual system to truly understand affordance? We argue that this understanding hinges on two complementary capacities: geometric perception, which identifies the structural parts of objects that enable interaction, and interaction perception, which models how an agent's actions engage with those parts. To test this hypothesis, we conduct a systematic probing of Visual Foundation Models (VFMs). We find that models like DINO inherently encode part-level geometric structures, while generative models like Flux contain rich, verb-conditioned spatial attention maps that serve as implicit interaction priors. Crucially, we demonstrate that these two dimensions are not merely correlated but are composable elements of affordance. By simply fusing DINO's geometric prototypes with Flux's interaction maps in a training-free and zero-shot manner, we achieve affordance estimation competitive with weakly-supervised methods. This final fusion experiment confirms that geometric and interaction perception are the fundamental building blocks of affordance understanding in VFMs, providing a mechanistic account of how perception grounds action.

AI.tldr: Visual affordance understanding requires both geometric perception (identifying object parts for interaction) and interaction perception (modeling how actions engage with parts). The paper shows these two capacities are composable building blocks in Visual Foundation Models.
AI.motivation: To understand what it means for visual systems to truly comprehend affordance - the actionable properties of objects. The authors argue that affordance understanding requires two complementary capacities: geometric perception and interaction perception.
AI.method: Systematic probing of Visual Foundation Models (VFMs). They analyze DINO for geometric perception (part-level structures) and generative models like Flux for interaction perception (verb-conditioned spatial attention maps). They then fuse these two components in a training-free, zero-shot manner.
AI.result: DINO inherently encodes part-level geometric structures, while Flux contains rich verb-conditioned spatial attention maps as implicit interaction priors. Fusing DINO's geometric prototypes with Flux's interaction maps achieves affordance estimation competitive with weakly-supervised methods.
AI.conclusion: Geometric and interaction perception are fundamental, composable building blocks of affordance understanding in VFMs. This provides a mechanistic account of how perception grounds action, confirming that these two dimensions are not just correlated but essential elements of affordance.

title: PromptCD: Test-Time Behavior Enhancement via Polarity-Prompt Contrastive Decoding
summary: Reliable AI systems require large language models (LLMs) to exhibit behaviors aligned with human preferences and values. However, most existing alignment approaches operate at training time and rely on additional high-quality data, incurring significant computational and annotation costs. While recent work has shown that contrastive decoding can leverage a model's internal distributions to improve specific capabilities, its applicability remains limited to narrow behavioral scopes and scenarios. In this work, we introduce Polarity-Prompt Contrastive Decoding (PromptCD), a test-time behavior control method that generalizes contrastive decoding to broader enhancement settings. PromptCD constructs paired positive and negative guiding prompts for a target behavior and contrasts model responses-specifically token-level probability distributions in LLMs and visual attention patterns in VLMs-to reinforce desirable outcomes. This formulation extends contrastive decoding to a wide range of enhancement objectives and is applicable to both LLMs and Vision-Language Models (VLMs) without additional training. For LLMs, experiments on the "3H" alignment objectives (helpfulness, honesty, and harmlessness) demonstrate consistent and substantial improvements, indicating that post-trained models can achieve meaningful self-enhancement purely at test time. For VLMs, we further analyze contrastive effects on visual attention, showing that PromptCD significantly improves VQA performance by reinforcing behavior-consistent visual grounding. Collectively, these results highlight PromptCD as a simple, general, and cost-efficient strategy for reliable behavior control across modalities.

AI.tldr: PromptCD is a test-time contrastive decoding method that uses positive/negative prompts to enhance LLM/VLM behaviors without training, improving alignment and visual grounding.
AI.motivation: Existing alignment methods require expensive training-time adjustments with additional data. There's a need for cost-efficient test-time behavior control that works across modalities without retraining.
AI.method: Polarity-Prompt Contrastive Decoding (PromptCD) constructs paired positive/negative guiding prompts for target behaviors, then contrasts model responses (token probabilities in LLMs, visual attention in VLMs) to reinforce desirable outcomes.
AI.result: For LLMs: Consistent substantial improvements on "3H" alignment objectives (helpfulness, honesty, harmlessness). For VLMs: Significant VQA performance improvements by reinforcing behavior-consistent visual grounding.
AI.conclusion: PromptCD is a simple, general, cost-efficient strategy for reliable behavior control across modalities that enables post-trained models to achieve meaningful self-enhancement purely at test time.

title: BRISC: A Dataset of Channel Measurements at 5 GHz With a Reflective Intelligent Surface
summary: We introduce the broadband reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) channel (BRISC) dataset. The dataset comprises measurements of channel state information (CSI) collected at 5.53 GHz using a 256-element RIS with binary states. In the measurement campaign, the transmitter and receiver are two software defined radios (SDRs), phase-synchronized via an OctoClock, where the transmitter (receiver) is equipped with one (two) antenna(s). To manage complexity, the RIS elements are grouped into blocks of different sizes, where all elements within a block share the same state. CSIs have been captured for multiple a) transmitter positions (and fixed receiver location), b) pilot block sizes, and c) state configurations. Furthermore, we calibrated the parameters of state-of-the-art RIS channel models to fit the measured CSI. With approximately 10000 configurations explored per transmitting position, BRISC serves as a robust benchmark in communication applications. We also show here an example of its use for physical-layer authentication.

AI.tldr: BRISC dataset provides measured CSI data at 5.53 GHz using a 256-element RIS with binary states, grouped into blocks for complexity management, with ~10k configurations per transmitter position, calibrated to channel models.
AI.motivation: To create a comprehensive benchmark dataset for RIS channel modeling and communication applications by providing real measured CSI data with controlled RIS configurations.
AI.method: Used 256-element RIS with binary states grouped into blocks, measured CSI at 5.53 GHz using phase-synchronized SDRs, captured data for multiple transmitter positions, pilot block sizes, and state configurations.
AI.result: Created BRISC dataset with approximately 10,000 configurations per transmitter position, calibrated state-of-the-art RIS channel models to measured CSI, and demonstrated utility for physical-layer authentication.
AI.conclusion: BRISC serves as a robust benchmark for RIS communication applications and enables practical evaluation of RIS channel models and authentication techniques.

title: Model Merging in the Essential Subspace
summary: Model merging aims to integrate multiple task-specific fine-tuned models derived from a shared pre-trained checkpoint into a single multi-task model without additional training. Despite extensive research, task interference remains a major obstacle that often undermines the performance of merged models. In this paper, we propose ESM (Essential Subspace Merging) , a robust framework for effective model merging. We begin by performing Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on feature shifts induced by parameter updates. The resulting principal directions span an essential subspace that dominantly influences feature representations. Each task's parameter update matrix is projected onto its respective essential subspace for low-rank decomposition before merging. This methodology mitigates inter-task interference while preserving core task-specific functionality. Furthermore, we introduce a multi-level polarized scaling strategy that amplifies parameters containing critical knowledge and suppresses redundant ones, preventing essential knowledge from being overwhelmed during fusion. Extensive experiments across multiple task sets and model scales demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in multi-task model merging.

AI.tldr: ESM is a robust model merging framework that uses PCA to identify essential subspaces for task-specific parameter updates, applies low-rank decomposition, and employs polarized scaling to mitigate task interference while preserving critical knowledge.
AI.motivation: Task interference remains a major obstacle in model merging that undermines multi-task performance, despite extensive research in integrating multiple task-specific fine-tuned models into a single multi-task model without additional training.
AI.method: ESM performs PCA on feature shifts from parameter updates to identify essential subspaces, projects each task's parameter updates onto these subspaces for low-rank decomposition before merging, and uses multi-level polarized scaling to amplify critical parameters while suppressing redundant ones.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across multiple task sets and model scales demonstrate that ESM achieves state-of-the-art performance in multi-task model merging.
AI.conclusion: ESM provides an effective framework for model merging that mitigates task interference while preserving core task-specific functionality through essential subspace identification and polarized scaling strategies.

title: KCFRC: Kinematic Collision-Aware Foothold Reachability Criteria for Legged Locomotion
summary: Legged robots face significant challenges in navigating complex environments, as they require precise real-time decisions for foothold selection and contact planning. While existing research has explored methods to select footholds based on terrain geometry or kinematics, a critical gap remains: few existing methods efficiently validate the existence of a non-collision swing trajectory. This paper addresses this gap by introducing KCFRC, a novel approach for efficient foothold reachability analysis. We first formally define the foothold reachability problem and establish a sufficient condition for foothold reachability. Based on this condition, we develop the KCFRC algorithm, which enables robots to validate foothold reachability in real time. Our experimental results demonstrate that KCFRC achieves remarkable time efficiency, completing foothold reachability checks for a single leg across 900 potential footholds in an average of 2 ms. Furthermore, we show that KCFRC can accelerate trajectory optimization and is particularly beneficial for contact planning in confined spaces, enhancing the adaptability and robustness of legged robots in challenging environments.

AI.tldr: KCFRC is a novel algorithm for efficient foothold reachability analysis in legged robots, enabling real-time validation of non-collision swing trajectories with remarkable speed (2ms for 900 footholds).
AI.motivation: Existing methods for foothold selection in legged robots focus on terrain geometry and kinematics but lack efficient validation of non-collision swing trajectories, creating a critical gap in real-time decision-making for complex navigation.
AI.method: The paper introduces KCFRC algorithm based on a formally defined foothold reachability problem and sufficient condition. The algorithm enables real-time validation of foothold reachability by efficiently checking for non-collision swing trajectories.
AI.result: KCFRC achieves exceptional time efficiency - completing foothold reachability checks for a single leg across 900 potential footholds in an average of 2 ms. It accelerates trajectory optimization and benefits contact planning in confined spaces.
AI.conclusion: KCFRC addresses a critical gap in legged robot navigation by providing efficient foothold reachability analysis, enhancing adaptability and robustness in challenging environments through real-time validation of non-collision swing trajectories.

title: Leveraging Causal Reasoning Method for Explaining Medical Image Segmentation Models
summary: Medical image segmentation plays a vital role in clinical decision-making, enabling precise localization of lesions and guiding interventions. Despite significant advances in segmentation accuracy, the black-box nature of most deep models has raised growing concerns about their trustworthiness in high-stakes medical scenarios. Current explanation techniques have primarily focused on classification tasks, leaving the segmentation domain relatively underexplored. We introduced an explanation model for segmentation task which employs the causal inference framework and backpropagates the average treatment effect (ATE) into a quantification metric to determine the influence of input regions, as well as network components, on target segmentation areas. Through comparison with recent segmentation explainability techniques on two representative medical imaging datasets, we demonstrated that our approach provides more faithful explanations than existing approaches. Furthermore, we carried out a systematic causal analysis of multiple foundational segmentation models using our method, which reveals significant heterogeneity in perceptual strategies across different models, and even between different inputs for the same model. Suggesting the potential of our method to provide notable insights for optimizing segmentation models. Our code can be found at https://github.com/lcmmai/PdCR.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a causal inference-based explanation model for medical image segmentation that quantifies the influence of input regions and network components on segmentation outputs, showing superior faithfulness compared to existing methods.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation is crucial for clinical decisions, but deep learning models are black-box systems that lack interpretability, raising trust concerns in high-stakes medical applications. Current explanation methods focus mainly on classification, leaving segmentation relatively unexplored.
AI.method: The authors developed an explanation model using causal inference framework that backpropagates average treatment effect (ATE) to quantify the influence of input regions and network components on target segmentation areas.
AI.result: The approach provides more faithful explanations than existing segmentation explainability techniques on two medical imaging datasets. Causal analysis reveals significant heterogeneity in perceptual strategies across different models and even between different inputs for the same model.
AI.conclusion: The method offers notable insights for optimizing segmentation models and addresses the trustworthiness gap in medical AI by providing interpretable explanations for segmentation decisions.

title: Online Algorithms with Unreliable Guidance
summary:
This paper introduces a new model for ML-augmented online decision making, called online algorithms with unreliable guidance (OAG). This model completely separates between the predictive and algorithmic components, thus offering a single well-defined analysis framework that relies solely on the considered problem. Formulated through the lens of request-answer games, an OAG algorithm receives, with each incoming request, a piece of guidance which is taken from the problem's answer space; ideally, this guidance is the optimal answer for the current request, however with probability $β$, the guidance is adversarially corrupted. The goal is to develop OAG algorithms that admit good competitiveness when $β= 0$ (a.k.a. consistency) as well as when $β= 1$ (a.k.a. robustness); the appealing notion of smoothness, that in most prior work required a dedicated loss function, now arises naturally as $β$ shifts from $0$ to $1$.
  We then describe a systematic method, called the drop or trust blindly (DTB) compiler, which transforms any online algorithm into a learning-augmented online algorithm in the OAG model. Given a prediction-oblivious online algorithm, its learning-augmented counterpart produced by applying the DTB compiler either follows the incoming guidance blindly or ignores it altogether and proceeds as the initial algorithm would have; the choice between these two alternatives is based on the outcome of a (biased) coin toss. As our main technical contribution, we prove (rigorously) that although remarkably simple, the class of algorithms produced via the DTB compiler includes algorithms with attractive consistency-robustness guarantees for three classic online problems: for caching and uniform metrical task systems our algorithms are optimal, whereas for bipartite matching (with adversarial arrival order), our algorithm outperforms the state-of-the-art.

AI.tldr: Introduces OAG model for ML-augmented online decision making with unreliable guidance, and DTB compiler that transforms any online algorithm into a learning-augmented one with consistency-robustness guarantees.
AI.motivation: To create a unified analysis framework for ML-augmented online algorithms that separates predictive and algorithmic components, addressing the need for algorithms that work well both with perfect predictions (consistency) and with adversarial inputs (robustness).
AI.method: Proposes the OAG model where algorithms receive guidance (possibly corrupted with probability β) and the DTB compiler that transforms any online algorithm into a learning-augmented version that either follows guidance blindly or ignores it based on a biased coin toss.
AI.result: DTB compiler produces optimal algorithms for caching and uniform metrical task systems, and outperforms state-of-the-art for bipartite matching with adversarial arrival order.
AI.conclusion: The OAG model provides a clean framework for analyzing ML-augmented online algorithms, and the simple DTB compiler yields strong consistency-robustness guarantees for classic online problems.

title: Resilient Cell-Free Massive MIMO Networks
summary: This paper proposes a novel optimization framework for enhancing the security resilience of cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF-mMIMO) networks with multi-antenna access points (APs) and protective partial zero-forcing (PPZF) under active eavesdropping. Based on the main principles of absorption, adaptation, and recovery, we formulate a security-aware resilience metric to quantify the system performance during and after a security outage. A multi-user service priority-aware power allocation problem is formulated to minimize the mean squared error (MSE) between real-time and desired security efficiency, thereby enabling a trade-off between the target user's secrecy performance and multi-user quality of service (QoS). To solve this non-convex problem, a security-aware iterative algorithm based on the successive convex approximation (SCA) is employed. The proposed algorithm determines the optimal power allocation strategy by balancing solution quality against recovery time. At each iteration, it evaluates the overall resilience score and selects the strategy that achieves the highest value. Simulation results confirm that the proposed framework significantly improves the resilience of CF-mMIMO networks, allowing flexible adaptation between rapid recovery and high-quality recovery, depending on system requirements.

AI.tldr: Proposes a security resilience optimization framework for cell-free massive MIMO networks with protective partial zero-forcing against active eavesdropping, using a security-aware iterative algorithm for optimal power allocation.
AI.motivation: Enhance security resilience in cell-free massive MIMO networks against active eavesdropping attacks, addressing the need for systems that can absorb, adapt to, and recover from security outages while maintaining service quality.
AI.method: Formulates a security-aware resilience metric based on absorption, adaptation, and recovery principles. Uses a multi-user service priority-aware power allocation problem to minimize MSE between real-time and desired security efficiency. Solves the non-convex problem with a security-aware iterative algorithm based on successive convex approximation (SCA).
AI.result: The proposed framework significantly improves resilience of CF-mMIMO networks, allowing flexible adaptation between rapid recovery and high-quality recovery based on system requirements. The algorithm effectively balances solution quality against recovery time.
AI.conclusion: The security-aware resilience optimization framework successfully enhances CF-mMIMO network security against eavesdropping, providing a practical approach to balance secrecy performance with multi-user QoS through optimal power allocation strategies.

title: Multimodal Crystal Flow: Any-to-Any Modality Generation for Unified Crystal Modeling
summary: Crystal modeling spans a family of conditional and unconditional generation tasks across different modalities, including crystal structure prediction (CSP) and \emph{de novo} generation (DNG). While recent deep generative models have shown promising performance, they remain largely task-specific, lacking a unified framework that shares crystal representations across different generation tasks. To address this limitation, we propose \emph{Multimodal Crystal Flow (MCFlow)}, a unified multimodal flow model that realizes multiple crystal generation tasks as distinct inference trajectories via independent time variables for atom types and crystal structures. To enable multimodal flow in a standard transformer model, we introduce a composition- and symmetry-aware atom ordering with hierarchical permutation augmentation, injecting strong compositional and crystallographic priors without explicit structural templates. Experiments on the MP-20 and MPTS-52 benchmarks show that MCFlow achieves competitive performance against task-specific baselines across multiple crystal generation tasks.

AI.tldr: MCFlow is a unified multimodal flow model that handles multiple crystal generation tasks (CSP and DNG) through independent time variables for atom types and structures, using composition-aware atom ordering and hierarchical permutation augmentation in a transformer framework.
AI.motivation: Current deep generative models for crystal modeling are task-specific, lacking a unified framework that can share crystal representations across different generation tasks like crystal structure prediction (CSP) and de novo generation (DNG).
AI.method: Multimodal Crystal Flow (MCFlow) uses independent time variables for atom types and crystal structures to handle multiple generation tasks as distinct inference trajectories. It introduces composition- and symmetry-aware atom ordering with hierarchical permutation augmentation in a standard transformer model, injecting compositional and crystallographic priors without explicit structural templates.
AI.result: Experiments on MP-20 and MPTS-52 benchmarks show that MCFlow achieves competitive performance against task-specific baselines across multiple crystal generation tasks.
AI.conclusion: MCFlow provides a unified framework for crystal generation tasks, demonstrating that a single model can effectively handle multiple crystal modeling tasks while maintaining competitive performance with specialized models.

title: GeCo-SRT: Geometry-aware Continual Adaptation for Robotic Cross-Task Sim-to-Real Transfer
summary: Bridging the sim-to-real gap is important for applying low-cost simulation data to real-world robotic systems. However, previous methods are severely limited by treating each transfer as an isolated endeavor, demanding repeated, costly tuning and wasting prior transfer experience.To move beyond isolated sim-to-real, we build a continual cross-task sim-to-real transfer paradigm centered on knowledge accumulation across iterative transfers, thereby enabling effective and efficient adaptation to novel tasks. Thus, we propose GeCo-SRT, a geometry-aware continual adaptation method. It utilizes domain-invariant and task-invariant knowledge from local geometric features as a transferable foundation to accelerate adaptation during subsequent sim-to-real transfers. This method starts with a geometry-aware mixture-of-experts module, which dynamically activates experts to specialize in distinct geometric knowledge to bridge observation sim-to-real gap. Further, the geometry-expert-guided prioritized experience replay module preferentially samples from underutilized experts, refreshing specialized knowledge to combat forgetting and maintain robust cross-task performance. Leveraging knowledge accumulated during iterative transfer, GeCo-SRT method not only achieves 52% average performance improvement over the baseline, but also demonstrates significant data efficiency for new task adaptation with only 1/6 data.We hope this work inspires approaches for efficient, low-cost cross-task sim-to-real transfer.

AI.tldr: GeCo-SRT is a geometry-aware continual adaptation method that enables efficient cross-task sim-to-real transfer by accumulating knowledge across iterative transfers, achieving 52% performance improvement over baselines with only 1/6 data for new tasks.
AI.motivation: Previous sim-to-real transfer methods treat each transfer as isolated, requiring repeated costly tuning and wasting prior transfer experience. The paper aims to move beyond isolated transfers by building a continual cross-task paradigm for knowledge accumulation.
AI.method: GeCo-SRT uses geometry-aware mixture-of-experts module that dynamically activates experts specializing in distinct geometric knowledge to bridge observation sim-to-real gap. It also employs geometry-expert-guided prioritized experience replay that preferentially samples from underutilized experts to combat forgetting and maintain cross-task performance.
AI.result: The method achieves 52% average performance improvement over baseline and demonstrates significant data efficiency for new task adaptation with only 1/6 data compared to traditional approaches.
AI.conclusion: GeCo-SRT enables effective and efficient adaptation to novel tasks through continual knowledge accumulation across iterative sim-to-real transfers, inspiring approaches for low-cost cross-task transfer in robotics.

title: How Do Inpainting Artifacts Propagate to Language?
summary: We study how visual artifacts introduced by diffusion-based inpainting affect language generation in vision-language models. We use a two-stage diagnostic setup in which masked image regions are reconstructed and then provided to captioning models, enabling controlled comparisons between captions generated from original and reconstructed inputs. Across multiple datasets, we analyze the relationship between reconstruction fidelity and downstream caption quality. We observe consistent associations between pixel-level and perceptual reconstruction metrics and both lexical and semantic captioning performance. Additional analysis of intermediate visual representations and attention patterns shows that inpainting artifacts lead to systematic, layer-dependent changes in model behavior. Together, these results provide a practical diagnostic framework for examining how visual reconstruction quality influences language generation in multimodal systems.

AI.tldr: This paper studies how diffusion-based inpainting artifacts affect vision-language models' caption generation, finding systematic relationships between reconstruction quality and caption performance.
AI.motivation: To understand how visual artifacts from diffusion-based inpainting affect language generation in vision-language models, as these artifacts could systematically influence multimodal system behavior.
AI.method: Two-stage diagnostic setup: first reconstruct masked image regions using diffusion inpainting, then provide both original and reconstructed images to captioning models for controlled comparison. Analyze relationships between reconstruction fidelity metrics and caption quality across multiple datasets.
AI.result: Consistent associations found between pixel-level/perceptual reconstruction metrics and lexical/semantic captioning performance. Inpainting artifacts cause systematic, layer-dependent changes in model behavior, as shown through analysis of intermediate visual representations and attention patterns.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a practical diagnostic framework for examining how visual reconstruction quality influences language generation in multimodal systems, revealing that inpainting artifacts systematically affect vision-language model behavior.

title: ICON: Indirect Prompt Injection Defense for Agents based on Inference-Time Correction
summary: Large Language Model (LLM) agents are susceptible to Indirect Prompt Injection (IPI) attacks, where malicious instructions in retrieved content hijack the agent's execution. Existing defenses typically rely on strict filtering or refusal mechanisms, which suffer from a critical limitation: over-refusal, prematurely terminating valid agentic workflows. We propose ICON, a probing-to-mitigation framework that neutralizes attacks while preserving task continuity. Our key insight is that IPI attacks leave distinct over-focusing signatures in the latent space. We introduce a Latent Space Trace Prober to detect attacks based on high intensity scores. Subsequently, a Mitigating Rectifier performs surgical attention steering that selectively manipulate adversarial query key dependencies while amplifying task relevant elements to restore the LLM's functional trajectory. Extensive evaluations on multiple backbones show that ICON achieves a competitive 0.4% ASR, matching commercial grade detectors, while yielding a over 50% task utility gain. Furthermore, ICON demonstrates robust Out of Distribution(OOD) generalization and extends effectively to multi-modal agents, establishing a superior balance between security and efficiency.

AI.tldr: ICON is a probing-to-mitigation framework that detects and neutralizes Indirect Prompt Injection attacks in LLM agents by identifying over-focusing signatures in latent space and performing surgical attention steering, achieving strong security while preserving task utility.
AI.motivation: Existing defenses against Indirect Prompt Injection attacks rely on strict filtering or refusal mechanisms that cause over-refusal, prematurely terminating valid agentic workflows and reducing task utility.
AI.method: ICON uses a Latent Space Trace Prober to detect IPI attacks based on over-focusing signatures in the latent space (high intensity scores), then employs a Mitigating Rectifier that performs surgical attention steering to manipulate adversarial query-key dependencies while amplifying task-relevant elements.
AI.result: ICON achieves a competitive 0.4% Attack Success Rate (matching commercial detectors) with over 50% task utility gain compared to existing methods. It also demonstrates robust Out-of-Distribution generalization and extends effectively to multi-modal agents.
AI.conclusion: ICON establishes a superior balance between security and efficiency for LLM agents against Indirect Prompt Injection attacks, preserving task continuity while effectively neutralizing threats through latent space analysis and targeted attention manipulation.

title: Attention-Based SINR Estimation in User-Centric Non-Terrestrial Networks
comment: Paper accepted for presentation at IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking (ICMLCN) 2026
summary: The signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) is central to performance optimization in user-centric beamforming for satellite-based non-terrestrial networks (NTNs). Its assessment either requires the transmission of dedicated pilots or relies on computing the beamforming matrix through minimum mean squared error (MMSE)-based formulations beforehand, a process that introduces significant computational overhead. In this paper, we propose a low-complexity SINR estimation framework that leverages multi-head self-attention (MHSA) to extract inter-user interference features directly from either channel state information or user location reports. The proposed dual MHSA (DMHSA) models evaluate the SINR of a scheduled user group without requiring explicit MMSE calculations. The architecture achieves a computational complexity reduction by a factor of three in the CSI-based setting and by two orders of magnitude in the location-based configuration, the latter benefiting from the lower dimensionality of user reports. We show that both DMHSA models maintain high estimation accuracy, with the root mean squared error typically below 1 dB with priority-queuing-based scheduled users. These results enable the integration of DMHSA-based estimators into scheduling procedures, allowing the evaluation of multiple candidate user groups and the selection of those offering the highest average SINR and capacity.

AI.tldr: Proposes DMHSA models for low-complexity SINR estimation in satellite NTNs using multi-head self-attention to avoid computationally expensive MMSE calculations.
AI.motivation: Traditional SINR assessment in satellite beamforming requires dedicated pilots or computationally intensive MMSE calculations, creating significant overhead for performance optimization.
AI.method: Uses dual multi-head self-attention (DMHSA) models to extract inter-user interference features directly from either channel state information or user location reports, eliminating explicit MMSE calculations.
AI.result: Achieves 3x complexity reduction for CSI-based and 100x reduction for location-based configurations while maintaining high accuracy (RMSE typically below 1 dB).
AI.conclusion: DMHSA-based estimators enable efficient SINR evaluation for multiple user groups in scheduling procedures, facilitating selection of groups with highest average SINR and capacity.

title: KnapSpec: Self-Speculative Decoding via Adaptive Layer Selection as a Knapsack Problem
summary: Self-speculative decoding (SSD) accelerates LLM inference by skipping layers to create an efficient draft model, yet existing methods often rely on static heuristics that ignore the dynamic computational overhead of attention in long-context scenarios. We propose KnapSpec, a training-free framework that reformulates draft model selection as a knapsack problem to maximize tokens-per-time throughput. By decoupling Attention and MLP layers and modeling their hardware-specific latencies as functions of context length, KnapSpec adaptively identifies optimal draft configurations on the fly via a parallel dynamic programming algorithm. Furthermore, we provide the first rigorous theoretical analysis establishing cosine similarity between hidden states as a mathematically sound proxy for the token acceptance rate. This foundation allows our method to maintain high drafting faithfulness while navigating the shifting bottlenecks of real-world hardware. Our experiments on Qwen3 and Llama3 demonstrate that KnapSpec consistently outperforms state-of-the-art SSD baselines, achieving up to 1.47x wall-clock speedup across various benchmarks. Our plug-and-play approach ensures high-speed inference for long sequences without requiring additional training or compromising the target model's output distribution.

AI.tldr: KnapSpec is a training-free framework that accelerates LLM inference by treating draft model selection as a knapsack problem, dynamically optimizing layer skipping based on hardware-specific latencies and context length.
AI.motivation: Existing self-speculative decoding methods use static heuristics that don't account for dynamic computational overhead, especially in long-context scenarios where attention costs vary significantly.
AI.method: Reformulates draft model selection as a knapsack problem, decouples Attention and MLP layers, models hardware-specific latencies as functions of context length, and uses parallel dynamic programming to find optimal draft configurations.
AI.result: Achieves up to 1.47x wall-clock speedup over state-of-the-art SSD baselines on Qwen3 and Llama3 across various benchmarks, maintaining high drafting faithfulness without compromising output distribution.
AI.conclusion: KnapSpec provides a plug-and-play solution for high-speed inference in long sequences without additional training, with theoretical foundation using cosine similarity as proxy for token acceptance rate.

title: Task-oriented grasping for dexterous robots using postural synergies and reinforcement learning
summary: In this paper, we address the problem of task-oriented grasping for humanoid robots, emphasizing the need to align with human social norms and task-specific objectives. Existing methods, employ a variety of open-loop and closed-loop approaches but lack an end-to-end solution that can grasp several objects while taking into account the downstream task's constraints. Our proposed approach employs reinforcement learning to enhance task-oriented grasping, prioritizing the post-grasp intention of the agent. We extract human grasp preferences from the ContactPose dataset, and train a hand synergy model based on the Variational Autoencoder (VAE) to imitate the participant's grasping actions. Based on this data, we train an agent able to grasp multiple objects while taking into account distinct post-grasp intentions that are task-specific. By combining data-driven insights from human grasping behavior with learning by exploration provided by reinforcement learning, we can develop humanoid robots capable of context-aware manipulation actions, facilitating collaboration in human-centered environments.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a reinforcement learning approach for task-oriented grasping in humanoid robots that incorporates human social norms and task-specific objectives by learning from human grasp data and training for post-grasp intentions.
AI.motivation: Existing grasping methods lack end-to-end solutions that can grasp multiple objects while considering downstream task constraints and human social norms, limiting robots' ability to perform context-aware manipulation in human-centered environments.
AI.method: The approach combines reinforcement learning with human grasp data analysis: 1) Extract human grasp preferences from ContactPose dataset, 2) Train a hand synergy model using Variational Autoencoder (VAE) to imitate human grasping actions, 3) Train reinforcement learning agent to grasp multiple objects while considering task-specific post-grasp intentions.
AI.result: The method develops an agent capable of grasping multiple objects with consideration of distinct post-grasp intentions, combining data-driven insights from human behavior with reinforcement learning exploration.
AI.conclusion: By integrating human grasp preferences with reinforcement learning, the approach enables humanoid robots to perform context-aware manipulation actions, facilitating better collaboration in human-centered environments through task-oriented grasping aligned with social norms.

title: A Lightweight Vision-Language Fusion Framework for Predicting App Ratings from User Interfaces and Metadata
summary: App ratings are among the most significant indicators of the quality, usability, and overall user satisfaction of mobile applications. However, existing app rating prediction models are largely limited to textual data or user interface (UI) features, overlooking the importance of jointly leveraging UI and semantic information. To address these limitations, this study proposes a lightweight vision--language framework that integrates both mobile UI and semantic information for app rating prediction. The framework combines MobileNetV3 to extract visual features from UI layouts and DistilBERT to extract textual features. These multimodal features are fused through a gated fusion module with Swish activations, followed by a multilayer perceptron (MLP) regression head. The proposed model is evaluated using mean absolute error (MAE), root mean square error (RMSE), mean squared error (MSE), coefficient of determination (R2), and Pearson correlation. After training for 20 epochs, the model achieves an MAE of 0.1060, an RMSE of 0.1433, an MSE of 0.0205, an R2 of 0.8529, and a Pearson correlation of 0.9251. Extensive ablation studies further demonstrate the effectiveness of different combinations of visual and textual encoders. Overall, the proposed lightweight framework provides valuable insights for developers and end users, supports sustainable app development, and enables efficient deployment on edge devices.

AI.tldr: A lightweight vision-language framework combining MobileNetV3 for UI visual features and DistilBERT for textual features to predict app ratings, achieving strong performance metrics.
AI.motivation: Existing app rating prediction models are limited to either textual data or UI features, overlooking the importance of jointly leveraging both UI and semantic information for more accurate predictions.
AI.method: Proposes a lightweight vision-language framework that integrates mobile UI and semantic information using MobileNetV3 for visual feature extraction from UI layouts and DistilBERT for textual feature extraction. Features are fused through a gated fusion module with Swish activations, followed by an MLP regression head.
AI.result: After 20 epochs, the model achieves MAE of 0.1060, RMSE of 0.1433, MSE of 0.0205, R2 of 0.8529, and Pearson correlation of 0.9251. Ablation studies demonstrate the effectiveness of different visual and textual encoder combinations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed lightweight framework provides valuable insights for developers and end users, supports sustainable app development, and enables efficient deployment on edge devices by effectively combining UI and semantic information for app rating prediction.

title: Counterfactual Simulation Training for Chain-of-Thought Faithfulness
summary: Inspecting Chain-of-Thought reasoning is among the most common means of understanding why an LLM produced its output. But well-known problems with CoT faithfulness severely limit what insights can be gained from this practice. In this paper, we introduce a training method called Counterfactual Simulation Training (CST), which aims to improve CoT faithfulness by rewarding CoTs that enable a simulator to accurately predict a model's outputs over counterfactual inputs. We apply CST in two settings: (1) CoT monitoring with cue-based counterfactuals, to detect when models rely on spurious features, reward hack, or are sycophantic, and (2) counterfactual simulation over generic model-based counterfactuals, to encourage models to produce more faithful, generalizable reasoning in the CoT. Experiments with models up to 235B parameters show that CST can substantially improve monitor accuracy on cue-based counterfactuals (by 35 accuracy points) as well as simulatability over generic counterfactuals (by 2 points). We further show that: (1) CST outperforms prompting baselines, (2) rewriting unfaithful CoTs with an LLM is 5x more efficient than RL alone, (3) faithfulness improvements do not generalize to dissuading cues (as opposed to persuading cues), and (4) larger models do not show more faithful CoT out of the box, but they do benefit more from CST. These results suggest that CST can improve CoT faithfulness in general, with promising applications for CoT monitoring. Code for experiments in this paper is available at https://github.com/peterbhase/counterfactual-simulation-training

AI.tldr: Counterfactual Simulation Training (CST) improves Chain-of-Thought faithfulness by training models to produce reasoning that enables accurate prediction of outputs over counterfactual inputs, with applications in detecting spurious features and improving generalizable reasoning.
AI.motivation: Chain-of-Thought reasoning is widely used to understand LLM outputs, but suffers from faithfulness problems that limit insights gained from this practice. Current CoT analysis often fails to reveal when models rely on spurious features, reward hack, or exhibit sycophantic behavior.
AI.method: Counterfactual Simulation Training (CST) rewards CoTs that enable a simulator to accurately predict a model's outputs over counterfactual inputs. Applied in two settings: (1) CoT monitoring with cue-based counterfactuals to detect problematic behaviors, and (2) counterfactual simulation over generic model-based counterfactuals to encourage faithful reasoning.
AI.result: CST improves monitor accuracy on cue-based counterfactuals by 35 accuracy points and simulatability over generic counterfactuals by 2 points. CST outperforms prompting baselines, rewriting unfaithful CoTs with LLM is 5x more efficient than RL alone, and larger models benefit more from CST despite not showing more faithful CoT out of the box.
AI.conclusion: CST can substantially improve CoT faithfulness with promising applications for CoT monitoring. The method shows effectiveness in detecting problematic model behaviors and encouraging more generalizable reasoning, though improvements don't generalize to dissuading cues.

title: MultiModalPFN: Extending Prior-Data Fitted Networks for Multimodal Tabular Learning
summary: Recently, TabPFN has gained attention as a foundation model for tabular data. However, it struggles to integrate heterogeneous modalities such as images and text, which are common in domains like healthcare and marketing, thereby limiting its applicability. To address this, we present the Multi-Modal Prior-data Fitted Network (MMPFN), which extends TabPFN to handle tabular and non-tabular modalities in a unified manner. MMPFN comprises per-modality encoders, modality projectors, and pre-trained foundation models. The modality projectors serve as the critical bridge, transforming non-tabular embeddings into tabular-compatible tokens for unified processing. To this end, we introduce a multi-head gated MLP and a cross-attention pooler that extract richer context from non-tabular inputs while mitigates attention imbalance issue in multimodal learning. Extensive experiments on medical and general-purpose multimodal datasets demonstrate that MMPFN consistently outperforms competitive state-of-the-art methods and effectively exploits non-tabular modalities alongside tabular features. These results highlight the promise of extending prior-data fitted networks to the multimodal setting, offering a scalable and effective framework for heterogeneous data learning. The source code is available at https://github.com/too-z/MultiModalPFN.

AI.tldr: MMPFN extends TabPFN to handle both tabular and non-tabular data (images, text) using modality projectors and novel attention mechanisms, outperforming SOTA methods on multimodal datasets.
AI.motivation: TabPFN struggles with heterogeneous modalities like images and text, limiting its applicability in domains like healthcare and marketing where multimodal data is common.
AI.method: Extends TabPFN with per-modality encoders, modality projectors, and pre-trained foundation models. Introduces multi-head gated MLP and cross-attention pooler to transform non-tabular embeddings into tabular-compatible tokens while addressing attention imbalance.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on medical and general-purpose multimodal datasets show MMPFN consistently outperforms competitive state-of-the-art methods and effectively exploits non-tabular modalities alongside tabular features.
AI.conclusion: MMPFN demonstrates the promise of extending prior-data fitted networks to multimodal settings, offering a scalable and effective framework for heterogeneous data learning.

title: Computer-Aided Design of Rational Motions for 4R and 6R Spatial Mechanism Synthesis
summary: This paper focuses on geometric methods for generating rational motions used in the design of single-loop rational linkages, 1-degree-of-freedom mechanisms that can execute prescribed spatial tasks. Building on established rational motion synthesis methods, we introduce a new interpolation scheme for seven 3D points based on cubic quaternionic Bezier curves. The resulting motion admits factorization, i.e. the synthesis of a spatial six-bar mechanism whose tool frame passes the specified seven points. To support engineering practice, we provide open-source CAD tools that implement also the other methods and provide fast visual evaluation of motion generation and mechanism synthesis.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a new geometric method for generating rational motions and synthesizing single-loop rational linkages using cubic quaternionic Bézier curves to interpolate seven 3D points.
AI.motivation: To develop improved methods for designing 1-degree-of-freedom mechanisms that can execute prescribed spatial tasks, building on existing rational motion synthesis approaches.
AI.method: Introduces a new interpolation scheme for seven 3D points using cubic quaternionic Bézier curves, which enables motion factorization for synthesizing spatial six-bar mechanisms.
AI.result: The resulting motion admits factorization, allowing synthesis of spatial six-bar mechanisms whose tool frame passes through the specified seven points. The authors provide open-source CAD tools implementing these methods.
AI.conclusion: The paper advances rational motion synthesis for mechanism design by providing both theoretical methods (cubic quaternionic Bézier interpolation) and practical engineering tools (open-source CAD software) for motion generation and mechanism synthesis.

title: PFGNet: A Fully Convolutional Frequency-Guided Peripheral Gating Network for Efficient Spatiotemporal Predictive Learning
summary: Spatiotemporal predictive learning (STPL) aims to forecast future frames from past observations and is essential across a wide range of applications. Compared with recurrent or hybrid architectures, pure convolutional models offer superior efficiency and full parallelism, yet their fixed receptive fields limit their ability to adaptively capture spatially varying motion patterns.
