AI.tldr: Proposes Interactive Enhanced Driving Dataset (IEDD) to address data sparsity and multimodal alignment issues in Vision-Language-Action models for autonomous driving.
AI.motivation: Current autonomous driving development lacks robust interactive capabilities due to sparse interactive scenarios and poor multimodal alignment in existing datasets, limiting VLA model development.
AI.method: Develops scalable pipeline to mine million-level interactive segments from naturalistic driving data using interactive trajectories, creates IEDD-VQA dataset with synthetic BEV videos where semantic actions are strictly aligned with structured language.
AI.result: Creates comprehensive IEDD dataset, provides benchmark results evaluating ten mainstream Vision Language Models, demonstrates dataset's reuse value for assessing and fine-tuning autonomous driving reasoning capabilities.
AI.conclusion: IEDD addresses critical data limitations in autonomous driving research, enabling better evaluation and development of interactive reasoning capabilities in VLA models through high-quality, aligned multimodal data.

title: Qwen-BIM: developing large language model for BIM-based design with domain-specific benchmark and dataset
summary: As the construction industry advances toward digital transformation, BIM (Building Information Modeling)-based design has become a key driver supporting intelligent construction. Despite Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown potential in promoting BIM-based design, the lack of specific datasets and LLM evaluation benchmarks has significantly hindered the performance of LLMs. Therefore, this paper addresses this gap by proposing: 1) an evaluation benchmark for BIM-based design together with corresponding quantitative indicators to evaluate the performance of LLMs, 2) a method for generating textual data from BIM and constructing corresponding BIM-derived datasets for LLM evaluation and fine-tuning, and 3) a fine-tuning strategy to adapt LLMs for BIM-based design. Results demonstrate that the proposed domain-specific benchmark effectively and comprehensively assesses LLM capabilities, highlighting that general LLMs are still incompetent for domain-specific tasks. Meanwhile, with the proposed benchmark and datasets, Qwen-BIM is developed and achieves a 21.0% average increase in G-Eval score compared to the base LLM model. Notably, with only 14B parameters, performance of Qwen-BIM is comparable to that of general LLMs with 671B parameters for BIM-based design tasks. Overall, this study develops the first domain-specific LLM for BIM-based design by introducing a comprehensive benchmark and high-quality dataset, which provide a solid foundation for developing BIM-related LLMs in various fields.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the first domain-specific LLM for BIM-based design (Qwen-BIM) with a comprehensive evaluation benchmark, dataset generation method, and fine-tuning strategy, achieving performance comparable to much larger general LLMs.
AI.motivation: The construction industry's digital transformation relies on BIM-based design, but LLMs lack specific datasets and evaluation benchmarks for this domain, hindering their performance in BIM applications.
AI.method: 1) Created an evaluation benchmark with quantitative indicators for BIM-based design LLMs; 2) Developed a method to generate textual data from BIM and construct BIM-derived datasets; 3) Proposed a fine-tuning strategy to adapt LLMs for BIM-based design.
AI.result: Qwen-BIM achieves 21.0% average increase in G-Eval score compared to base LLM. With only 14B parameters, it performs comparably to general LLMs with 671B parameters on BIM-based design tasks.
AI.conclusion: This study develops the first domain-specific LLM for BIM-based design, providing a comprehensive benchmark and high-quality dataset that serve as a foundation for future BIM-related LLM development across various fields.

title: In-context Pre-trained Time-Series Foundation Models adapt to Unseen Tasks
summary: Time-series foundation models (TSFMs) have demonstrated strong generalization capabilities across diverse datasets and tasks. However, existing foundation models are typically pre-trained to enhance performance on specific tasks and often struggle to generalize to unseen tasks without fine-tuning. To address this limitation, we propose augmenting TSFMs with In-Context Learning (ICL) capabilities, enabling them to perform test-time inference by dynamically adapting to input-output relationships provided within the context. Our framework, In-Context Time-series Pre-training (ICTP), restructures the original pre-training data to equip the backbone TSFM with ICL capabilities, enabling adaptation to unseen tasks. Experiments demonstrate that ICT improves the performance of state-of-the-art TSFMs by approximately 11.4% on unseen tasks without requiring fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: TSFMs gain ICL capabilities via ICTP framework, improving performance on unseen tasks by ~11.4% without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Existing time-series foundation models struggle to generalize to unseen tasks without fine-tuning, as they're typically pre-trained for specific tasks rather than being adaptable to new tasks at inference time.
AI.method: Proposed In-Context Time-series Pre-training (ICTP) framework that restructures pre-training data to equip backbone TSFMs with in-context learning capabilities, enabling dynamic adaptation to input-output relationships provided within context during test-time inference.
AI.result: ICT improves performance of state-of-the-art TSFMs by approximately 11.4% on unseen tasks without requiring fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: Augmenting TSFMs with in-context learning capabilities through ICTP framework enables better generalization to unseen tasks without fine-tuning, addressing a key limitation of existing foundation models.

title: A Micro-Macro Model of Encounter-Driven Information Diffusion in Robot Swarms
summary: In this paper, we propose the problem of Encounter-Driven Information Diffusion (EDID). In EDID, robots are allowed to exchange information only upon meeting. Crucially, EDID assumes that the robots are not allowed to schedule their meetings. As such, the robots have no means to anticipate when, where, and who they will meet. As a step towards the design of storage and routing algorithms for EDID, in this paper we propose a model of information diffusion that captures the essential dynamics of EDID. The model is derived from first principles and is composed of two levels: a micro model, based on a generalization of the concept of `mean free path'; and a macro model, which captures the global dynamics of information diffusion. We validate the model through extensive robot simulations, in which we consider swarm size, communication range, environment size, and different random motion regimes. We conclude the paper with a discussion of the implications of this model on the algorithms that best support information diffusion according to the parameters of interest.

AI.tldr: Proposes Encounter-Driven Information Diffusion (EDID) problem where robots exchange info only upon random meetings without scheduling, develops a two-level diffusion model, validates with simulations, and discusses algorithm implications.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of information diffusion in robotic systems where robots can only exchange information during random, unscheduled encounters, without the ability to anticipate when, where, or who they will meet.
AI.method: Develops a two-level information diffusion model: 1) micro model based on generalized 'mean free path' concept, and 2) macro model capturing global diffusion dynamics. Validates through extensive robot simulations varying swarm size, communication range, environment size, and random motion regimes.
AI.result: The paper validates the proposed EDID model through simulations, showing how different parameters (swarm size, communication range, environment size, motion regimes) affect information diffusion in encounter-driven systems.
AI.conclusion: The model provides a foundation for designing storage and routing algorithms for EDID systems, with implications for how algorithm design should adapt to different system parameters to optimize information diffusion in encounter-driven scenarios.

title: Efficient and Explainable End-to-End Autonomous Driving via Masked Vision-Language-Action Diffusion
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) and Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have emerged as promising candidates for end-to-end autonomous driving. However, these models typically face challenges in inference latency, action precision, and explainability. Existing autoregressive approaches struggle with slow token-by-token generation, while prior diffusion-based planners often rely on verbose, general-purpose language tokens that lack explicit geometric structure. In this work, we propose Masked Vision-Language-Action Diffusion for Autonomous Driving (MVLAD-AD), a novel framework designed to bridge the gap between efficient planning and semantic explainability via a masked vision-language-action diffusion model. Unlike methods that force actions into the language space, we introduce a discrete action tokenization strategy that constructs a compact codebook of kinematically feasible waypoints from real-world driving distributions. Moreover, we propose geometry-aware embedding learning to ensure that embeddings in the latent space approximate physical geometric metrics. Finally, an action-priority decoding strategy is introduced to prioritize trajectory generation. Extensive experiments on nuScenes and derived benchmarks demonstrate that MVLAD-AD achieves superior efficiency and outperforms state-of-the-art autoregressive and diffusion baselines in planning precision, while providing high-fidelity and explainable reasoning.

AI.tldr: MVLAD-AD is a masked vision-language-action diffusion framework for autonomous driving that improves planning efficiency, precision, and explainability through discrete action tokenization and geometry-aware embeddings.
AI.motivation: Current LLM/VLM approaches for autonomous driving suffer from slow inference latency, poor action precision, and lack of explainability. Autoregressive methods are too slow, while diffusion-based planners use verbose language tokens without explicit geometric structure.
AI.method: Proposes MVLAD-AD with three key innovations: 1) Discrete action tokenization that creates a compact codebook of kinematically feasible waypoints from real-world driving distributions, 2) Geometry-aware embedding learning to ensure latent space embeddings approximate physical geometric metrics, and 3) Action-priority decoding strategy to prioritize trajectory generation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on nuScenes and derived benchmarks show MVLAD-AD achieves superior efficiency and outperforms state-of-the-art autoregressive and diffusion baselines in planning precision, while providing high-fidelity and explainable reasoning.
AI.conclusion: MVLAD-AD successfully bridges the gap between efficient planning and semantic explainability in autonomous driving through a masked vision-language-action diffusion approach with discrete action tokenization and geometry-aware learning.

title: Pressure Reveals Character: Behavioural Alignment Evaluation at Depth
summary: Evaluating alignment in language models requires testing how they behave under realistic pressure, not just what they claim they would do. While alignment failures increasingly cause real-world harm, comprehensive evaluation frameworks with realistic multi-turn scenarios remain lacking. We introduce an alignment benchmark spanning 904 scenarios across six categories -- Honesty, Safety, Non-Manipulation, Robustness, Corrigibility, and Scheming -- validated as realistic by human raters. Our scenarios place models under conflicting instructions, simulated tool access, and multi-turn escalation to reveal behavioural tendencies that single-turn evaluations miss. Evaluating 24 frontier models using LLM judges validated against human annotations, we find that even top-performing models exhibit gaps in specific categories, while the majority of models show consistent weaknesses across the board. Factor analysis reveals that alignment behaves as a unified construct (analogous to the g-factor in cognitive research) with models scoring high on one category tending to score high on others. We publicly release the benchmark and an interactive leaderboard to support ongoing evaluation, with plans to expand scenarios in areas where we observe persistent weaknesses and to add new models as they are released.

AI.tldr: Researchers created a comprehensive alignment benchmark with 904 realistic multi-turn scenarios across 6 categories to test language models under pressure, revealing that even top models have alignment gaps and alignment behaves as a unified construct.
AI.motivation: Current alignment evaluations lack realistic multi-turn scenarios that test how models actually behave under pressure, not just what they claim they would do. Alignment failures are causing increasing real-world harm, necessitating better evaluation frameworks.
AI.method: Created a benchmark with 904 scenarios across 6 categories (Honesty, Safety, Non-Manipulation, Robustness, Corrigibility, Scheming) validated by human raters. Used multi-turn scenarios with conflicting instructions, simulated tool access, and escalation. Evaluated 24 frontier models using LLM judges validated against human annotations.
AI.result: Even top-performing models exhibit gaps in specific categories, while most models show consistent weaknesses across the board. Factor analysis reveals alignment behaves as a unified construct (similar to g-factor in cognitive research) - models scoring high in one category tend to score high in others.
AI.conclusion: The benchmark reveals critical alignment weaknesses in current models and shows alignment functions as a unified construct. The researchers publicly released the benchmark and interactive leaderboard to support ongoing evaluation and plan to expand scenarios in areas of persistent weakness.

title: QuantVLA: Scale-Calibrated Post-Training Quantization for Vision-Language-Action Models
summary: Vision-language-action (VLA) models unify perception, language, and control for embodied agents but face significant challenges in practical deployment due to rapidly increasing compute and memory demands, especially as models scale to longer horizons and larger backbones. To address these bottlenecks, we introduce QuantVLA, a training-free post-training quantization (PTQ) framework that, to our knowledge, is the first PTQ approach for VLA systems and the first to successfully quantize a diffusion transformer (DiT) action head. QuantVLA incorporates three scale-calibrated components: (1) a selective quantization layout that integerizes all linear layers in both the language backbone and the DiT while keeping attention projections in floating point to preserve the original operator schedule; (2) attention temperature matching, a lightweight per-head scaling mechanism that stabilizes attention logits and is folded into the dequantization scales at inference; and (3) output head balancing, a per-layer residual interface calibration that mitigates post-projection energy drift. The framework requires no additional training, uses only a small unlabeled calibration buffer, and supports integer kernels for low-bit weights and activations while leaving the architecture unchanged. Across representative VLA models on LIBERO, QuantVLA exceeds the task success rates of full-precision baselines, achieves about 70% relative memory savings on the quantized components, and delivers a 1.22x speedup in end-to-end inference latency, providing a practical pathway toward scalable low-bit embodied intelligence under strict compute, memory, and power constraints.

AI.tldr: QuantVLA is a training-free post-training quantization framework for vision-language-action models that reduces compute/memory demands while maintaining or improving performance.
AI.motivation: VLA models face practical deployment challenges due to rapidly increasing compute and memory demands as models scale, especially for longer horizons and larger backbones.
AI.method: QuantVLA uses three scale-calibrated components: 1) selective quantization layout that integerizes linear layers while keeping attention projections in FP, 2) attention temperature matching for stabilizing attention logits, and 3) output head balancing to mitigate post-projection energy drift.
AI.result: QuantVLA exceeds full-precision baseline task success rates on LIBERO benchmark, achieves ~70% relative memory savings on quantized components, and delivers 1.22x speedup in end-to-end inference latency.
AI.conclusion: QuantVLA provides a practical pathway toward scalable low-bit embodied intelligence under strict compute, memory, and power constraints without requiring additional training.

title: HALO: A Unified Vision-Language-Action Model for Embodied Multimodal Chain-of-Thought Reasoning
summary: Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have shown strong performance in robotic manipulation, but often struggle in long-horizon or out-of-distribution scenarios due to the lack of explicit mechanisms for multimodal reasoning and anticipating how the world will evolve under action. Recent works introduce textual chain-of-thought or visual subgoal prediction within VLA models to reason, but still fail to offer a unified human-like reasoning framework for joint textual reasoning, visual foresight, and action prediction. To this end, we propose HALO, a unified VLA model that enables embodied multimodal chain-of-thought (EM-CoT) reasoning through a sequential process of textual task reasoning, visual subgoal prediction for fine-grained guidance, and EM-CoT-augmented action prediction. We instantiate HALO with a Mixture-of-Transformers (MoT) architecture that decouples semantic reasoning, visual foresight, and action prediction into specialized experts while allowing seamless cross-expert collaboration. To enable HALO learning at scale, we introduce an automated pipeline to synthesize EM-CoT training data along with a carefully crafted training recipe. Extensive experiments demonstrate that: (1) HALO achieves superior performance in both simulated and real-world environments, surpassing baseline policy pi_0 by 34.1% on RoboTwin benchmark; (2) all proposed components of the training recipe and EM-CoT design help improve task success rate; and (3) HALO exhibits strong generalization capabilities under aggressive unseen environmental randomization with our proposed EM-CoT reasoning.

AI.tldr: HALO is a unified Vision-Language-Action model that introduces embodied multimodal chain-of-thought reasoning to improve robotic manipulation in long-horizon and out-of-distribution scenarios.
AI.motivation: Current VLA models struggle with long-horizon or out-of-distribution scenarios due to lack of explicit multimodal reasoning and action anticipation mechanisms. Existing approaches with textual chain-of-thought or visual subgoal prediction fail to provide unified human-like reasoning combining textual reasoning, visual foresight, and action prediction.
AI.method: HALO enables embodied multimodal chain-of-thought (EM-CoT) reasoning through sequential textual task reasoning, visual subgoal prediction, and EM-CoT-augmented action prediction. It uses a Mixture-of-Transformers architecture with specialized experts for semantic reasoning, visual foresight, and action prediction that collaborate seamlessly. An automated pipeline synthesizes EM-CoT training data with a carefully crafted training recipe.
AI.result: HALO achieves superior performance in both simulated and real-world environments, surpassing baseline policy pi_0 by 34.1% on RoboTwin benchmark. All proposed components of the training recipe and EM-CoT design improve task success rate. HALO exhibits strong generalization capabilities under aggressive unseen environmental randomization with EM-CoT reasoning.
AI.conclusion: HALO provides a unified VLA framework that successfully integrates embodied multimodal chain-of-thought reasoning, enabling improved performance and generalization in robotic manipulation tasks through specialized expert collaboration and automated training data synthesis.

title: PropFly: Learning to Propagate via On-the-Fly Supervision from Pre-trained Video Diffusion Models
comment: The first two authors contributed equally to this work (equal contribution)
summary: Propagation-based video editing enables precise user control by propagating a single edited frame into following frames while maintaining the original context such as motion and structures. However, training such models requires large-scale, paired (source and edited) video datasets, which are costly and complex to acquire. Hence, we propose the PropFly, a training pipeline for Propagation-based video editing, relying on on-the-Fly supervision from pre-trained video diffusion models (VDMs) instead of requiring off-the-shelf or precomputed paired video editing datasets. Specifically, our PropFly leverages one-step clean latent estimations from intermediate noised latents with varying Classifier-Free Guidance (CFG) scales to synthesize diverse pairs of 'source' (low-CFG) and 'edited' (high-CFG) latents on-the-fly. The source latent serves as structural information of the video, while the edited latent provides the target transformation for learning propagation. Our pipeline enables an additional adapter attached to the pre-trained VDM to learn to propagate edits via Guidance-Modulated Flow Matching (GMFM) loss, which guides the model to replicate the target transformation. Our on-the-fly supervision ensures the model to learn temporally consistent and dynamic transformations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our PropFly significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art methods on various video editing tasks, producing high-quality editing results.

AI.tldr: PropFly: Training pipeline for propagation-based video editing using on-the-fly supervision from pre-trained video diffusion models instead of paired video datasets.
AI.motivation: Training propagation-based video editing models requires large-scale paired video datasets (source and edited), which are costly and complex to acquire. Existing methods face data scarcity challenges.
AI.method: PropFly uses on-the-fly supervision from pre-trained VDMs by synthesizing diverse 'source' (low-CFG) and 'edited' (high-CFG) latent pairs using one-step clean latent estimations with varying Classifier-Free Guidance scales. An adapter attached to the pre-trained VDM learns propagation via Guidance-Modulated Flow Matching (GMFM) loss.
AI.result: PropFly significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods on various video editing tasks, producing high-quality editing results with temporal consistency and dynamic transformations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed PropFly pipeline successfully addresses the data scarcity problem in propagation-based video editing by leveraging on-the-fly supervision from pre-trained VDMs, enabling effective training without requiring paired video datasets while achieving superior performance.

title: Diagnosing Causal Reasoning in Vision-Language Models via Structured Relevance Graphs
summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) achieve strong performance on visual question answering benchmarks, yet often rely on spurious correlations rather than genuine causal reasoning. Existing evaluations primarily assess the correctness of the answers, making it unclear whether failures arise from limited reasoning capability or from misidentifying causally relevant information. We introduce Vision-Language Causal Graphs (VLCGs), a structured, query-conditioned representation that explicitly encodes causally relevant objects, attributes, relations, and scene-grounded assumptions. Building on this representation, we present ViLCaR, a diagnostic benchmark comprising tasks for Causal Attribution, Causal Inference, and Question Answering, along with graph-aligned evaluation metrics that assess relevance identification beyond final answer accuracy. Experiments in state-of-the-art LVLMs show that injecting structured relevance information significantly improves attribution and inference consistency compared to zero-shot and standard in-context learning. These findings suggest that current limitations in LVLM causal reasoning stem primarily from insufficient structural guidance rather than a lack of reasoning capacity.

AI.tldr: LVLMs often use spurious correlations instead of genuine causal reasoning. The paper introduces VLCGs (structured causal graphs) and ViLCaR benchmark to diagnose causal reasoning failures, showing that structured relevance information improves performance.
AI.motivation: Current LVLMs rely on spurious correlations rather than genuine causal reasoning, and existing evaluations only assess answer correctness without determining whether failures come from limited reasoning capability or misidentifying causally relevant information.
AI.method: Introduces Vision-Language Causal Graphs (VLCGs) - structured, query-conditioned representations that encode causally relevant objects, attributes, relations, and scene-grounded assumptions. Creates ViLCaR benchmark with tasks for Causal Attribution, Causal Inference, and Question Answering, with graph-aligned evaluation metrics.
AI.result: Injecting structured relevance information significantly improves attribution and inference consistency in state-of-the-art LVLMs compared to zero-shot and standard in-context learning. Shows current limitations stem from insufficient structural guidance rather than lack of reasoning capacity.
AI.conclusion: The primary limitation in LVLM causal reasoning is insufficient structural guidance, not reasoning capacity. Structured causal representations like VLCGs can significantly improve causal reasoning performance by providing explicit relevance information.

title: CaDrift: A Time-dependent Causal Generator of Drifting Data Streams
summary: This work presents Causal Drift Generator (CaDrift), a time-dependent synthetic data generator framework based on Structural Causal Models (SCMs). The framework produces a virtually infinite combination of data streams with controlled shift events and time-dependent data, making it a tool to evaluate methods under evolving data. CaDrift synthesizes various distributional and covariate shifts by drifting mapping functions of the SCM, which change underlying cause-and-effect relationships between features and the target. In addition, CaDrift models occasional perturbations by leveraging interventions in causal modeling. Experimental results show that, after distributional shift events, the accuracy of classifiers tends to drop, followed by a gradual retrieval, confirming the generator's effectiveness in simulating shifts. The framework has been made available on GitHub.

AI.tldr: CaDrift is a synthetic data generator framework using Structural Causal Models to create time-dependent data streams with controlled distributional shifts and interventions for evaluating ML methods on evolving data.
AI.motivation: Need tools to evaluate machine learning methods under evolving data with distributional shifts, as real-world data often changes over time and existing evaluation frameworks lack controlled simulation of causal drift events.
AI.method: Uses Structural Causal Models (SCMs) to generate synthetic data streams by drifting mapping functions of SCMs to create distributional/covariate shifts, and leverages causal interventions to model occasional perturbations.
AI.result: Experimental results show classifier accuracy drops after distributional shift events followed by gradual recovery, confirming the generator's effectiveness in simulating realistic shifts. Framework is publicly available on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: CaDrift provides a valuable tool for evaluating ML methods on evolving data with controlled causal drift, enabling better assessment of model robustness to distributional changes over time.

title: ActionReasoning: Robot Action Reasoning in 3D Space with LLM for Robotic Brick Stacking
comment: 8 pages, 5 figures, accepted by the 2026 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation
summary: Classical robotic systems typically rely on custom planners designed for constrained environments. While effective in restricted settings, these systems lack generalization capabilities, limiting the scalability of embodied AI and general-purpose robots. Recent data-driven Vision-Language-Action (VLA) approaches aim to learn policies from large-scale simulation and real-world data. However, the continuous action space of the physical world significantly exceeds the representational capacity of linguistic tokens, making it unclear if scaling data alone can yield general robotic intelligence. To address this gap, we propose ActionReasoning, an LLM-driven framework that performs explicit action reasoning to produce physics-consistent, prior-guided decisions for robotic manipulation. ActionReasoning leverages the physical priors and real-world knowledge already encoded in Large Language Models (LLMs) and structures them within a multi-agent architecture. We instantiate this framework on a tractable case study of brick stacking, where the environment states are assumed to be already accurately measured. The environmental states are then serialized and passed to a multi-agent LLM framework that generates physics-aware action plans. The experiments demonstrate that the proposed multi-agent LLM framework enables stable brick placement while shifting effort from low-level domain-specific coding to high-level tool invocation and prompting, highlighting its potential for broader generalization. This work introduces a promising approach to bridging perception and execution in robotic manipulation by integrating physical reasoning with LLMs.

AI.tldr: ActionReasoning: LLM-driven framework for robotic manipulation that performs explicit physics-aware action reasoning using multi-agent LLM architecture, demonstrated on brick stacking tasks.
AI.motivation: Classical robotic planners lack generalization capabilities, limiting scalable embodied AI. While data-driven VLA approaches exist, the continuous action space of physical world exceeds linguistic token capacity, questioning whether scaling data alone can achieve general robotic intelligence.
AI.method: Proposes ActionReasoning framework that leverages physical priors and real-world knowledge encoded in LLMs, structured within multi-agent architecture. Environmental states are serialized and passed to multi-agent LLM framework to generate physics-aware action plans. Demonstrated on brick stacking with accurately measured environment states.
AI.result: Experiments show the multi-agent LLM framework enables stable brick placement while shifting effort from low-level domain-specific coding to high-level tool invocation and prompting, highlighting potential for broader generalization.
AI.conclusion: Introduces promising approach to bridge perception and execution in robotic manipulation by integrating physical reasoning with LLMs, moving toward more generalizable robotic intelligence.

title: Long-Term Multi-Session 3D Reconstruction Under Substantial Appearance Change
summary: Long-term environmental monitoring requires the ability to reconstruct and align 3D models across repeated site visits separated by months or years. However, existing Structure-from-Motion (SfM) pipelines implicitly assume near-simultaneous image capture and limited appearance change, and therefore fail when applied to long-term monitoring scenarios such as coral reef surveys, where substantial visual and structural change is common. In this paper, we show that the primary limitation of current approaches lies in their reliance on post-hoc alignment of independently reconstructed sessions, which is insufficient under large temporal appearance change. We address this limitation by enforcing cross-session correspondences directly within a joint SfM reconstruction. Our approach combines complementary handcrafted and learned visual features to robustly establish correspondences across large temporal gaps, enabling the reconstruction of a single coherent 3D model from imagery captured years apart, where standard independent and joint SfM pipelines break down. We evaluate our method on long-term coral reef datasets exhibiting significant real-world change, and demonstrate consistent joint reconstruction across sessions in cases where existing methods fail to produce coherent reconstructions. To ensure scalability to large datasets, we further restrict expensive learned feature matching to a small set of likely cross-session image pairs identified via visual place recognition, which reduces computational cost and improves alignment robustness.

AI.tldr: A novel SfM approach for long-term environmental monitoring that enforces cross-session correspondences within joint reconstruction, combining handcrafted and learned features to handle large temporal appearance changes.
AI.motivation: Existing SfM pipelines fail in long-term monitoring scenarios like coral reef surveys because they assume near-simultaneous capture and limited appearance change, whereas real-world monitoring involves months/years gaps with substantial visual and structural changes.
AI.method: Enforces cross-session correspondences directly within joint SfM reconstruction using complementary handcrafted and learned visual features. Uses visual place recognition to identify likely cross-session image pairs, restricting expensive learned feature matching to these subsets for scalability.
AI.result: Successfully reconstructs single coherent 3D models from imagery captured years apart on coral reef datasets with significant real-world change, where standard independent and joint SfM pipelines break down.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach enables robust long-term environmental monitoring by addressing the fundamental limitation of existing methods through direct cross-session correspondence enforcement within joint reconstruction, making it practical for real-world applications with large temporal gaps.

title: Predicting Sentence Acceptability Judgments in Multimodal Contexts
summary: Previous work has examined the capacity of deep neural networks (DNNs), particularly transformers, to predict human sentence acceptability judgments, both independently of context, and in document contexts. We consider the effect of prior exposure to visual images (i.e., visual context) on these judgments for humans and large language models (LLMs). Our results suggest that, in contrast to textual context, visual images appear to have little if any impact on human acceptability ratings. However, LLMs display the compression effect seen in previous work on human judgments in document contexts. Different sorts of LLMs are able to predict human acceptability judgments to a high degree of accuracy, but in general, their performance is slightly better when visual contexts are removed. Moreover, the distribution of LLM judgments varies among models, with Qwen resembling human patterns, and others diverging from them. LLM-generated predictions on sentence acceptability are highly correlated with their normalised log probabilities in general. However, the correlations decrease when visual contexts are present, suggesting that a higher gap exists between the internal representations of LLMs and their generated predictions in the presence of visual contexts. Our experimental work suggests interesting points of similarity and of difference between human and LLM processing of sentences in multimodal contexts.

AI.tldr: Visual context has minimal impact on human sentence acceptability judgments but affects LLMs differently, with LLMs showing compression effects and varying performance across models when visual context is present.
AI.motivation: To investigate how visual context (prior exposure to images) affects sentence acceptability judgments in both humans and LLMs, compared to previous work on textual/document context effects.
AI.method: Examined human and LLM sentence acceptability judgments with and without visual context, comparing different LLM types (including Qwen), and analyzing correlations between LLM predictions and their normalized log probabilities.
AI.result: Visual images have little impact on human ratings, but LLMs show compression effects. LLMs predict human judgments accurately but perform slightly better without visual context. Qwen resembles human patterns while other models diverge. Correlations between LLM predictions and log probabilities decrease with visual context.
AI.conclusion: Visual context affects humans and LLMs differently, revealing interesting similarities and differences in multimodal sentence processing between human cognition and LLM architectures.

title: Emergent Manifold Separability during Reasoning in Large Language Models
comment: Alexandre Polo and Chanwoo Chun contributed equally to this work"
summary: Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting significantly improves reasoning in Large Language Models, yet the temporal dynamics of the underlying representation geometry remain poorly understood. We investigate these dynamics by applying Manifold Capacity Theory (MCT) to a compositional Boolean logic task, allowing us to quantify the linear separability of latent representations without the confounding factors of probe training. Our analysis reveals that reasoning manifests as a transient geometric pulse, where concept manifolds are untangled into linearly separable subspaces immediately prior to computation and rapidly compressed thereafter. This behavior diverges from standard linear probe accuracy, which remains high long after computation, suggesting a fundamental distinction between information that is merely retrievable and information that is geometrically prepared for processing. We interpret this phenomenon as \emph{Dynamic Manifold Management}, a mechanism where the model dynamically modulates representational capacity to optimize the bandwidth of the residual stream throughout the reasoning chain.

AI.tldr: CoT reasoning creates transient geometric pulses where concept manifolds become linearly separable just before computation, then rapidly compress - a process called Dynamic Manifold Management.
AI.motivation: While CoT prompting improves reasoning in LLMs, the temporal dynamics of representation geometry during reasoning remain poorly understood. The paper aims to investigate how latent representations evolve geometrically during reasoning processes.
AI.method: Applied Manifold Capacity Theory (MCT) to a compositional Boolean logic task to quantify linear separability of latent representations without probe training confounds. This allows direct analysis of representation geometry dynamics during reasoning.
AI.result: Reasoning manifests as a transient geometric pulse: concept manifolds untangle into linearly separable subspaces immediately before computation, then rapidly compress afterward. This differs from linear probe accuracy which remains high long after computation, revealing a distinction between retrievable information and geometrically prepared information.
AI.conclusion: The phenomenon is interpreted as Dynamic Manifold Management - a mechanism where models dynamically modulate representational capacity to optimize residual stream bandwidth throughout reasoning chains, preparing information geometrically for processing rather than just storing it.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Any-Angle Path Planning on Multi-Resolution 3D Grids
comment: 12 pages, 9 figures, 4 tables, accepted to RSS 2025, code is open-source: https://github.com/ethz-asl/wavestar
summary: Hierarchical, multi-resolution volumetric mapping approaches are widely used to represent large and complex environments as they can efficiently capture their occupancy and connectivity information. Yet widely used path planning methods such as sampling and trajectory optimization do not exploit this explicit connectivity information, and search-based methods such as A* suffer from scalability issues in large-scale high-resolution maps. In many applications, Euclidean shortest paths form the underpinning of the navigation system. For such applications, any-angle planning methods, which find optimal paths by connecting corners of obstacles with straight-line segments, provide a simple and efficient solution. In this paper, we present a method that has the optimality and completeness properties of any-angle planners while overcoming computational tractability issues common to search-based methods by exploiting multi-resolution representations. Extensive experiments on real and synthetic environments demonstrate the proposed approach's solution quality and speed, outperforming even sampling-based methods. The framework is open-sourced to allow the robotics and planning community to build on our research.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical volumetric mapping method for efficient any-angle path planning that exploits multi-resolution representations to achieve optimality while overcoming computational scalability issues in large environments.
AI.motivation: Existing path planning methods don't fully exploit the connectivity information in hierarchical volumetric maps. Sampling/trajectory optimization methods ignore this connectivity, while search-based methods like A* suffer from scalability issues in large-scale high-resolution maps.
AI.method: The method combines any-angle planning (which finds optimal paths by connecting obstacle corners with straight-line segments) with multi-resolution volumetric representations. This exploits the explicit connectivity information in hierarchical maps while maintaining computational tractability.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on real and synthetic environments show the approach outperforms even sampling-based methods in both solution quality and speed. The method achieves optimality and completeness properties while being computationally efficient.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework successfully bridges the gap between optimal any-angle planning and computational efficiency by leveraging multi-resolution representations. It's open-sourced to enable further development by the robotics and planning community.

title: Interaction-aware Representation Modeling with Co-occurrence Consistency for Egocentric Hand-Object Parsing
summary: A fine-grained understanding of egocentric human-environment interactions is crucial for developing next-generation embodied agents. One fundamental challenge in this area involves accurately parsing hands and active objects. While transformer-based architectures have demonstrated considerable potential for such tasks, several key limitations remain unaddressed: 1) existing query initialization mechanisms rely primarily on semantic cues or learnable parameters, demonstrating limited adaptability to changing active objects across varying input scenes; 2) previous transformer-based methods utilize pixel-level semantic features to iteratively refine queries during mask generation, which may introduce interaction-irrelevant content into the final embeddings; and 3) prevailing models are susceptible to "interaction illusion", producing physically inconsistent predictions. To address these issues, we propose an end-to-end Interaction-aware Transformer (InterFormer), which integrates three key components, i.e., a Dynamic Query Generator (DQG), a Dual-context Feature Selector (DFS), and the Conditional Co-occurrence (CoCo) loss. The DQG explicitly grounds query initialization in the spatial dynamics of hand-object contact, enabling targeted generation of interaction-aware queries for hands and various active objects. The DFS fuses coarse interactive cues with semantic features, thereby suppressing interaction-irrelevant noise and emphasizing the learning of interactive relationships. The CoCo loss incorporates hand-object relationship constraints to enhance physical consistency in prediction. Our model achieves state-of-the-art performance on both the EgoHOS and the challenging out-of-distribution mini-HOI4D datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness and strong generalization ability. Code and models are publicly available at https://github.com/yuggiehk/InterFormer.

AI.tldr: InterFormer: A transformer-based model for fine-grained hand-object interaction parsing that addresses query initialization limitations, interaction-irrelevant noise, and physical inconsistency through dynamic query generation, dual-context feature selection, and conditional co-occurrence loss.
AI.motivation: Existing transformer-based methods for parsing hands and active objects have three key limitations: 1) limited adaptability of query initialization to changing active objects, 2) introduction of interaction-irrelevant content during mask generation, and 3) susceptibility to "interaction illusion" producing physically inconsistent predictions.
AI.method: Proposes InterFormer with three components: Dynamic Query Generator (DQG) that grounds query initialization in hand-object contact dynamics, Dual-context Feature Selector (DFS) that fuses interactive cues with semantic features to suppress noise, and Conditional Co-occurrence (CoCo) loss that incorporates hand-object relationship constraints for physical consistency.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on both EgoHOS and the challenging out-of-distribution mini-HOI4D datasets, demonstrating effectiveness and strong generalization ability.
AI.conclusion: InterFormer successfully addresses key limitations in hand-object interaction parsing through its three novel components, providing an effective solution for fine-grained understanding of egocentric human-environment interactions with improved physical consistency and generalization.

title: HELP: HyperNode Expansion and Logical Path-Guided Evidence Localization for Accurate and Efficient GraphRAG
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) often struggle with inherent knowledge boundaries and hallucinations, limiting their reliability in knowledge-intensive tasks. While Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) mitigates these issues, it frequently overlooks structural interdependencies essential for multi-hop reasoning. Graph-based RAG approaches attempt to bridge this gap, yet they typically face trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency due to challenges such as costly graph traversals and semantic noise in LLM-generated summaries. In this paper, we propose HyperNode Expansion and Logical Path-Guided Evidence Localization strategies for GraphRAG (HELP), a novel framework designed to balance accuracy with practical efficiency through two core strategies: 1) HyperNode Expansion, which iteratively chains knowledge triplets into coherent reasoning paths abstracted as HyperNodes to capture complex structural dependencies and ensure retrieval accuracy; and 2) Logical Path-Guided Evidence Localization, which leverages precomputed graph-text correlations to map these paths directly to the corpus for superior efficiency. HELP avoids expensive random walks and semantic distortion, preserving knowledge integrity while drastically reducing retrieval latency. Extensive experiments demonstrate that HELP achieves competitive performance across multiple simple and multi-hop QA benchmarks and up to a 28.8$\times$ speedup over leading Graph-based RAG baselines.

AI.tldr: HELP is a GraphRAG framework that improves multi-hop reasoning by using HyperNode Expansion for accurate structural dependency capture and Logical Path-Guided Evidence Localization for efficient retrieval, achieving competitive QA performance with 28.8x speedup.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle with knowledge boundaries and hallucinations in knowledge-intensive tasks. While RAG helps, it overlooks structural interdependencies needed for multi-hop reasoning. Graph-based RAG approaches exist but face accuracy-efficiency trade-offs due to costly graph traversals and semantic noise in LLM-generated summaries.
AI.method: HELP framework with two core strategies: 1) HyperNode Expansion - iteratively chains knowledge triplets into coherent reasoning paths abstracted as HyperNodes to capture complex structural dependencies; 2) Logical Path-Guided Evidence Localization - leverages precomputed graph-text correlations to map paths directly to the corpus for efficiency. Avoids expensive random walks and semantic distortion.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show HELP achieves competitive performance across multiple simple and multi-hop QA benchmarks and achieves up to 28.8x speedup over leading Graph-based RAG baselines.
AI.conclusion: HELP successfully balances accuracy with practical efficiency in GraphRAG by capturing structural dependencies through HyperNodes while enabling efficient retrieval through precomputed correlations, addressing key limitations of existing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Molecular Representation Learning via Fragment-Based Self-Supervised Embedding Prediction
summary: Graph self-supervised learning (GSSL) has demonstrated strong potential for generating expressive graph embeddings without the need for human annotations, making it particularly valuable in domains with high labeling costs such as molecular graph analysis. However, existing GSSL methods mostly focus on node- or edge-level information, often ignoring chemically relevant substructures which strongly influence molecular properties. In this work, we propose Graph Semantic Predictive Network (GraSPNet), a hierarchical self-supervised framework that explicitly models both atomic-level and fragment-level semantics. GraSPNet decomposes molecular graphs into chemically meaningful fragments without predefined vocabularies and learns node- and fragment-level representations through multi-level message passing with masked semantic prediction at both levels. This hierarchical semantic supervision enables GraSPNet to learn multi-resolution structural information that is both expressive and transferable. Extensive experiments on multiple molecular property prediction benchmarks demonstrate that GraSPNet learns chemically meaningful representations and consistently outperforms state-of-the-art GSSL methods in transfer learning settings.

AI.tldr: GraSPNet is a hierarchical self-supervised learning framework for molecular graphs that models both atomic-level and fragment-level semantics through masked semantic prediction, outperforming existing methods in transfer learning.
AI.motivation: Existing graph self-supervised learning methods focus on node- or edge-level information but ignore chemically relevant substructures that strongly influence molecular properties, limiting their effectiveness in molecular analysis where labeling costs are high.
AI.method: GraSPNet decomposes molecular graphs into chemically meaningful fragments without predefined vocabularies, then learns node- and fragment-level representations through multi-level message passing with masked semantic prediction at both atomic and fragment levels.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple molecular property prediction benchmarks show that GraSPNet learns chemically meaningful representations and consistently outperforms state-of-the-art graph self-supervised learning methods in transfer learning settings.
AI.conclusion: The hierarchical semantic supervision in GraSPNet enables learning of multi-resolution structural information that is both expressive and transferable, making it particularly valuable for molecular graph analysis where human annotations are costly.

title: Squint: Fast Visual Reinforcement Learning for Sim-to-Real Robotics
comment: For website and code, see https://aalmuzairee.github.io/squint
summary: Visual reinforcement learning is appealing for robotics but expensive -- off-policy methods are sample-efficient yet slow; on-policy methods parallelize well but waste samples. Recent work has shown that off-policy methods can train faster than on-policy methods in wall-clock time for state-based control. Extending this to vision remains challenging, where high-dimensional input images complicate training dynamics and introduce substantial storage and encoding overhead. To address these challenges, we introduce Squint, a visual Soft Actor Critic method that achieves faster wall-clock training than prior visual off-policy and on-policy methods. Squint achieves this via parallel simulation, a distributional critic, resolution squinting, layer normalization, a tuned update-to-data ratio, and an optimized implementation. We evaluate on the SO-101 Task Set, a new suite of eight manipulation tasks in ManiSkill3 with heavy domain randomization, and demonstrate sim-to-real transfer to a real SO-101 robot. We train policies for 15 minutes on a single RTX 3090 GPU, with most tasks converging in under 6 minutes.

AI.tldr: Squint is a visual Soft Actor-Critic method that achieves faster wall-clock training than prior visual RL methods by using parallel simulation, distributional critic, resolution squinting, and optimized implementation.
AI.motivation: Visual reinforcement learning for robotics is expensive - off-policy methods are sample-efficient but slow, while on-policy methods parallelize well but waste samples. Extending fast wall-clock training from state-based control to vision remains challenging due to high-dimensional images, training dynamics, and storage/encoding overhead.
AI.method: Squint introduces a visual Soft Actor-Critic method with: parallel simulation, distributional critic, resolution squinting (reducing image resolution), layer normalization, tuned update-to-data ratio, and optimized implementation.
AI.result: Achieves faster wall-clock training than prior visual off-policy and on-policy methods. Trains policies in 15 minutes on a single RTX 3090 GPU, with most tasks converging in under 6 minutes. Successfully demonstrates sim-to-real transfer to a real SO-101 robot.
AI.conclusion: Squint successfully addresses the wall-clock training speed challenge in visual RL for robotics, enabling practical training times through architectural innovations and optimization techniques while maintaining sim-to-real transfer capability.

title: VAGNet: Grounding 3D Affordance from Human-Object Interactions in Videos
summary: 3D object affordance grounding aims to identify regions on 3D objects that support human-object interaction (HOI), a capability essential to embodied visual reasoning. However, most existing approaches rely on static visual or textual cues, neglecting that affordances are inherently defined by dynamic actions. As a result, they often struggle to localize the true contact regions involved in real interactions. We take a different perspective. Humans learn how to use objects by observing and imitating actions, not just by examining shapes. Motivated by this intuition, we introduce video-guided 3D affordance grounding, which leverages dynamic interaction sequences to provide functional supervision. To achieve this, we propose VAGNet, a framework that aligns video-derived interaction cues with 3D structure to resolve ambiguities that static cues cannot address. To support this new setting, we introduce PVAD, the first HOI video-3D pairing affordance dataset, providing functional supervision unavailable in prior works. Extensive experiments on PVAD show that VAGNet achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly outperforming static-based baselines. The code and dataset will be open publicly.

AI.tldr: VAGNet introduces video-guided 3D affordance grounding using dynamic interaction sequences to better localize contact regions for human-object interactions, outperforming static-based methods.
AI.motivation: Current 3D affordance grounding methods rely on static visual/textual cues, which fail to capture the dynamic nature of affordances defined by actions. Humans learn object use through observation and imitation of actions, not just shape examination.
AI.method: Proposes VAGNet framework that aligns video-derived interaction cues with 3D structure to resolve ambiguities. Introduces PVAD dataset - first HOI video-3D pairing affordance dataset providing functional supervision unavailable in prior works.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on PVAD show VAGNet achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly outperforming static-based baselines.
AI.conclusion: Video-guided approach using dynamic interaction sequences provides superior affordance grounding compared to static methods, with code and dataset to be publicly released.

title: Architecting AgentOS: From Token-Level Context to Emergent System-Level Intelligence
summary: The paradigm of Large Language Models is undergoing a fundamental transition from static inference engines to dynamic autonomous cognitive systems.While current research primarily focuses on scaling context windows or optimizing prompt engineering the theoretical bridge between micro scale token processing and macro scale systemic intelligence remains fragmented.This paper proposes AgentOS,a holistic conceptual framework that redefines the LLM as a "Reasoning Kernel" governed by structured operating system logic.Central to this architecture is Deep Context Management which conceptualizes the context window as an Addressable Semantic Space rather than a passive buffer.We systematically deconstruct the transition from discrete sequences to coherent cognitive states introducing mechanisms for Semantic Slicing and Temporal Alignment to mitigate cognitive drift in multi-agent orchestration.By mapping classical OS abstractions such as memory paging interrupt handling and process scheduling onto LLM native constructs, this review provides a rigorous roadmap for architecting resilient scalable and self-evolving cognitive environments.Our analysis asserts that the next frontier of AGI development lies in the architectural efficiency of system-level coordination.

AI.tldr: AgentOS proposes a conceptual framework that redefines LLMs as "Reasoning Kernels" with operating system logic, introducing Deep Context Management to treat context windows as Addressable Semantic Spaces rather than passive buffers.
AI.motivation: Current LLM research focuses on scaling context windows and prompt engineering, but lacks theoretical bridge between micro-scale token processing and macro-scale systemic intelligence. There's a need for architectural frameworks to enable dynamic autonomous cognitive systems.
AI.method: Proposes AgentOS framework that maps classical OS abstractions (memory paging, interrupt handling, process scheduling) onto LLM native constructs. Introduces Deep Context Management with Semantic Slicing and Temporal Alignment mechanisms to mitigate cognitive drift in multi-agent orchestration.
AI.result: Provides a rigorous roadmap for architecting resilient, scalable, and self-evolving cognitive environments by systematically deconstructing the transition from discrete sequences to coherent cognitive states.
AI.conclusion: The next frontier of AGI development lies in architectural efficiency of system-level coordination, moving beyond static inference engines to dynamic autonomous cognitive systems through structured operating system logic.

title: Momentum Guidance: Plug-and-Play Guidance for Flow Models
summary: Flow-based generative models have become a strong framework for high-quality generative modeling, yet pretrained models are rarely used in their vanilla conditional form: conditional samples without guidance often appear diffuse and lack fine-grained detail due to the smoothing effects of neural networks. Existing guidance techniques such as classifier-free guidance (CFG) improve fidelity but double the inference cost and typically reduce sample diversity. We introduce Momentum Guidance (MG), a new dimension of guidance that leverages the ODE trajectory itself. MG extrapolates the current velocity using an exponential moving average of past velocities and preserves the standard one-evaluation-per-step cost. It matches the effect of standard guidance without extra computation and can further improve quality when combined with CFG. Experiments demonstrate MG's effectiveness across benchmarks. Specifically, on ImageNet-256, MG achieves average improvements in FID of 36.68% without CFG and 25.52% with CFG across various sampling settings, attaining an FID of 1.597 at 64 sampling steps. Evaluations on large flow-based models like Stable Diffusion 3 and FLUX.1-dev further confirm consistent quality enhancements across standard metrics.

AI.tldr: Momentum Guidance (MG) improves flow-based generative models by using exponential moving average of past velocities from ODE trajectories, enhancing sample quality without extra inference cost.
AI.motivation: Pretrained flow-based models produce diffuse conditional samples lacking fine-grained detail due to neural network smoothing. Existing guidance techniques like classifier-free guidance improve fidelity but double inference cost and reduce sample diversity.
AI.method: Introduces Momentum Guidance (MG) that leverages the ODE trajectory by extrapolating current velocity using exponential moving average of past velocities. Preserves standard one-evaluation-per-step cost, can be combined with CFG.
AI.result: On ImageNet-256, MG achieves 36.68% FID improvement without CFG and 25.52% with CFG across various sampling settings, attaining FID of 1.597 at 64 steps. Consistent quality enhancements on Stable Diffusion 3 and FLUX.1-dev.
AI.conclusion: MG provides effective guidance for flow-based generative models that matches standard guidance effects without extra computation, significantly improving sample quality while maintaining inference efficiency.

title: Knowing the Unknown: Interpretable Open-World Object Detection via Concept Decomposition Model
summary: Open-world object detection (OWOD) requires incrementally detecting known categories while reliably identifying unknown objects. Existing methods primarily focus on improving unknown recall, yet overlook interpretability, often leading to known-unknown confusion and reduced prediction reliability. This paper aims to make the entire OWOD framework interpretable, enabling the detector to truly "knowing the unknown". To this end, we propose a concept-driven InterPretable OWOD framework(IPOW) by introducing a Concept Decomposition Model (CDM) for OWOD, which explicitly decomposes the coupled RoI features in Faster R-CNN into discriminative, shared, and background concepts. Discriminative concepts identify the most discriminative features to enlarge the distances between known categories, while shared and background concepts, due to their strong generalization ability, can be readily transferred to detect unknown categories. Leveraging the interpretable framework, we identify that known-unknown confusion arises when unknown objects fall into the discriminative space of known classes. To address this, we propose Concept-Guided Rectification (CGR) to further resolve such confusion. Extensive experiments show that IPOW significantly improves unknown recall while mitigating confusion, and provides concept-level interpretability for both known and unknown predictions.

AI.tldr: IPOW introduces an interpretable open-world object detection framework using concept decomposition to separate RoI features into discriminative, shared, and background concepts, enabling better unknown detection and reducing known-unknown confusion.
AI.motivation: Existing OWOD methods focus on unknown recall but lack interpretability, leading to known-unknown confusion and reduced prediction reliability. The paper aims to make OWOD interpretable so detectors can truly "know the unknown".
AI.method: Proposes IPOW framework with Concept Decomposition Model (CDM) that decomposes Faster R-CNN RoI features into discriminative (for known category separation), shared, and background concepts (for unknown detection). Also introduces Concept-Guided Rectification (CGR) to resolve confusion when unknowns fall into known discriminative spaces.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show IPOW significantly improves unknown recall while mitigating known-unknown confusion, and provides concept-level interpretability for both known and unknown predictions.
AI.conclusion: IPOW makes OWOD interpretable by decomposing features into meaningful concepts, enabling detectors to better understand unknowns while maintaining known category performance, addressing a key limitation in current OWOD approaches.

title: LogicGraph : Benchmarking Multi-Path Logical Reasoning via Neuro-Symbolic Generation and Verification
summary: Evaluations of large language models (LLMs) primarily emphasize convergent logical reasoning, where success is defined by producing a single correct proof. However, many real-world reasoning problems admit multiple valid derivations, requiring models to explore diverse logical paths rather than committing to one route. To address this limitation, we introduce LogicGraph, the first benchmark aimed to systematically evaluate multi-path logical reasoning, constructed via a neuro-symbolic framework that leverages backward logic generation and semantic instantiation. This pipeline yields solver-verified reasoning problems formalized by high-depth multi-path reasoning and inherent logical distractions, where each instance is associated with an exhaustive set of minimal proofs. We further propose a reference-free evaluation framework to rigorously assess model performance in both convergent and divergent regimes. Experiments on state-of-the-art language models reveal a common limitation: models tend to commit early to a single route and fail to explore alternatives, and the coverage gap grows substantially with reasoning depth. LogicGraph exposes this divergence gap and provides actionable insights to motivate future improvements. Our code and data will be released at https://github.com/kkkkarry/LogicGraph.

AI.tldr: LogicGraph is a new benchmark for evaluating multi-path logical reasoning in LLMs, revealing models' tendency to commit early to single solutions rather than exploring diverse valid proofs.
AI.motivation: Current LLM evaluations focus too much on convergent reasoning (single correct proofs), but real-world problems often have multiple valid solutions requiring exploration of diverse logical paths.
AI.method: Created LogicGraph benchmark using neuro-symbolic framework with backward logic generation and semantic instantiation, producing solver-verified problems with multiple minimal proofs and logical distractions.
AI.result: State-of-the-art LLMs show significant limitations: they commit early to single routes, fail to explore alternatives, and the coverage gap increases substantially with reasoning depth.
AI.conclusion: LogicGraph exposes the divergence gap in LLMs' reasoning capabilities and provides actionable insights to motivate future improvements in multi-path logical reasoning.

title: Quantitative Approximation Rates for Group Equivariant Learning
summary:
The universal approximation theorem establishes that neural networks can approximate any continuous function on a compact set. Later works in approximation theory provide quantitative approximation rates for ReLU networks on the class of $α$-Hölder functions $f: [0,1]^N \to \mathbb{R}$. The goal of this paper is to provide similar quantitative approximation results in the context of group equivariant learning, where the learned $α$-Hölder function is known to obey certain group symmetries. While there has been much interest in the literature in understanding the universal approximation properties of equivariant models, very few quantitative approximation results are known for equivariant models.
  In this paper, we bridge this gap by deriving quantitative approximation rates for several prominent group-equivariant and invariant architectures. The architectures that we consider include: the permutation-invariant Deep Sets architecture; the permutation-equivariant Sumformer and Transformer architectures; joint invariance to permutations and rigid motions using invariant networks based on frame averaging; and general bi-Lipschitz invariant models. Overall, we show that equally-sized ReLU MLPs and equivariant architectures are equally expressive over equivariant functions. Thus, hard-coding equivariance does not result in a loss of expressivity or approximation power in these models.

AI.tldr: The paper provides quantitative approximation rates for group-equivariant neural networks, showing that equivariant architectures have the same expressive power as standard MLPs for equivariant functions.
AI.motivation: While universal approximation theorems exist for standard neural networks, and quantitative rates are known for ReLU networks on Hölder functions, there's a gap in understanding quantitative approximation rates for group-equivariant models despite much interest in their universal approximation properties.
AI.method: The authors derive quantitative approximation rates for several prominent group-equivariant architectures including: permutation-invariant Deep Sets, permutation-equivariant Sumformer and Transformer architectures, networks invariant to permutations and rigid motions using frame averaging, and general bi-Lipschitz invariant models.
AI.result: The paper shows that equally-sized ReLU MLPs and equivariant architectures are equally expressive over equivariant functions, demonstrating that hard-coding equivariance does not result in loss of expressivity or approximation power.
AI.conclusion: Equivariant neural architectures maintain the same approximation capabilities as standard MLPs while incorporating symmetry constraints, providing theoretical justification for using equivariant models without sacrificing expressive power.

title: RecoverMark: Robust Watermarking for Localization and Recovery of Manipulated Faces
summary: The proliferation of AI-generated content has facilitated sophisticated face manipulation, severely undermining visual integrity and posing unprecedented challenges to intellectual property. In response, a common proactive defense leverages fragile watermarks to detect, localize, or even recover manipulated regions. However, these methods always assume an adversary unaware of the embedded watermark, overlooking their inherent vulnerability to watermark removal attacks. Furthermore, this fragility is exacerbated in the commonly used dual-watermark strategy that adds a robust watermark for image ownership verification, where mutual interference and limited embedding capacity reduce the fragile watermark's effectiveness. To address the gap, we propose RecoverMark, a watermarking framework that achieves robust manipulation localization, content recovery, and ownership verification simultaneously. Our key insight is twofold. First, we exploit a critical real-world constraint: an adversary must preserve the background's semantic consistency to avoid visual detection, even if they apply global, imperceptible watermark removal attacks. Second, using the image's own content (face, in this paper) as the watermark enhances extraction robustness. Based on these insights, RecoverMark treats the protected face content itself as the watermark and embeds it into the surrounding background. By designing a robust two-stage training paradigm with carefully crafted distortion layers that simulate comprehensive potential attacks and a progressive training strategy, RecoverMark achieves a robust watermark embedding in no fragile manner for image manipulation localization, recovery, and image IP protection simultaneously. Extensive experiments demonstrate the proposed RecoverMark's robustness against both seen and unseen attacks and its generalizability to in-distribution and out-of-distribution data.

AI.tldr: RecoverMark is a watermarking framework that uses the protected face content itself as a watermark embedded in the background, enabling robust manipulation localization, content recovery, and ownership verification simultaneously against watermark removal attacks.
AI.motivation: Existing fragile watermark methods for detecting AI-generated face manipulations are vulnerable to watermark removal attacks, especially in dual-watermark strategies where robust watermarks for ownership verification interfere with fragile watermarks, reducing effectiveness.
AI.method: Uses the protected face content itself as the watermark embedded into the surrounding background. Employs a robust two-stage training paradigm with distortion layers simulating comprehensive potential attacks and progressive training strategy for robust watermark embedding.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show RecoverMark's robustness against both seen and unseen attacks, with generalizability to in-distribution and out-of-distribution data, achieving simultaneous manipulation localization, content recovery, and IP protection.
AI.conclusion: RecoverMark addresses the vulnerability of existing fragile watermark methods by exploiting real-world constraints (background semantic consistency) and using image content as watermark, enabling robust protection against sophisticated AI-generated face manipulations.

title: Tool Building as a Path to "Superintelligence"
summary: The Diligent Learner framework suggests LLMs can achieve superintelligence via test-time search, provided a sufficient step-success probability $γ$. In this work, we design a benchmark to measure $γ$ on logical out-of-distribution inference. We construct a class of tasks involving GF(2) circuit reconstruction that grow more difficult with each reasoning step, and that are, from an information-theoretic standpoint, impossible to reliably solve unless the LLM carefully integrates all of the information provided. Our analysis demonstrates that while the $γ$ value for small LLMs declines superlinearly as depth increases, frontier models exhibit partial robustness on this task. Furthermore, we find that successful reasoning at scale is contingent upon precise tool calls, identifying tool design as a critical capability for LLMs to achieve general superintelligence through the Diligent Learner framework.

AI.tldr: LLMs need sufficient step-success probability (γ) for superintelligence via test-time search. The paper creates a benchmark measuring γ on logical OOD inference using GF(2) circuit reconstruction tasks that get harder with each step.
AI.motivation: To determine if LLMs can achieve superintelligence through the Diligent Learner framework, which requires maintaining a sufficient step-success probability (γ) during multi-step reasoning. The paper aims to measure γ on challenging logical reasoning tasks that require careful information integration.
AI.method: Designed a benchmark with GF(2) circuit reconstruction tasks that increase in difficulty with each reasoning step. These tasks are information-theoretically impossible to solve reliably unless LLMs integrate all provided information. Analyzed γ values across different model sizes and depths.
AI.result: Small LLMs show superlinear decline in γ as depth increases, while frontier models exhibit partial robustness. Successful reasoning at scale depends on precise tool calls, identifying tool design as critical for achieving superintelligence via the Diligent Learner framework.
AI.conclusion: Tool design is a critical capability for LLMs to achieve general superintelligence through the Diligent Learner framework. Frontier models show promising partial robustness on challenging logical reasoning tasks, but maintaining step-success probability remains a key challenge.

title: cc-Shapley: Measuring Multivariate Feature Importance Needs Causal Context
summary: Explainable artificial intelligence promises to yield insights into relevant features, thereby enabling humans to examine and scrutinize machine learning models or even facilitating scientific discovery. Considering the widespread technique of Shapley values, we find that purely data-driven operationalization of multivariate feature importance is unsuitable for such purposes. Even for simple problems with two features, spurious associations due to collider bias and suppression arise from considering one feature only in the observational context of the other, which can lead to misinterpretations. Causal knowledge about the data-generating process is required to identify and correct such misleading feature attributions. We propose cc-Shapley (causal context Shapley), an interventional modification of conventional observational Shapley values leveraging knowledge of the data's causal structure, thereby analyzing the relevance of a feature in the causal context of the remaining features. We show theoretically that this eradicates spurious association induced by collider bias. We compare the behavior of Shapley and cc-Shapley values on various, synthetic, and real-world datasets. We observe nullification or reversal of associations compared to univariate feature importance when moving from observational to cc-Shapley.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes cc-Shapley, a causal modification of Shapley values that eliminates spurious associations from collider bias by using causal knowledge of the data-generating process.
AI.motivation: Current observational Shapley values can produce misleading feature attributions due to collider bias and suppression effects, which undermines the goal of explainable AI to provide meaningful insights for human scrutiny and scientific discovery.
AI.method: The authors propose cc-Shapley (causal context Shapley), an interventional modification of conventional observational Shapley values that leverages knowledge of the data's causal structure to analyze feature relevance in the causal context of other features.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows cc-Shapley eradicates spurious associations induced by collider bias. Empirical comparisons on synthetic and real-world datasets show nullification or reversal of associations compared to univariate feature importance when moving from observational to cc-Shapley values.
AI.conclusion: Purely data-driven operationalization of multivariate feature importance is insufficient for explainable AI; causal knowledge is required to correct misleading feature attributions, and cc-Shapley provides a principled solution that eliminates spurious associations from collider bias.

title: Object-Scene-Camera Decomposition and Recomposition for Data-Efficient Monocular 3D Object Detection
summary: Monocular 3D object detection (M3OD) is intrinsically ill-posed, hence training a high-performance deep learning based M3OD model requires a humongous amount of labeled data with complicated visual variation from diverse scenes, variety of objects and camera poses.However, we observe that, due to strong human bias, the three independent entities, i.e., object, scene, and camera pose, are always tightly entangled when an image is captured to construct training data. More specifically, specific 3D objects are always captured in particular scenes with fixed camera poses, and hence lacks necessary diversity. Such tight entanglement induces the challenging issues of insufficient utilization and overfitting to uniform training data. To mitigate this, we propose an online object-scene-camera decomposition and recomposition data manipulation scheme to more efficiently exploit the training data.
